Ottawa,
August 27, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to requisition dated the 14th instant you may purchase the following for the Birch Island Indian Day School:

- 4 Brooms
- 6 Yds. printed broadcloth
- 5 " plain "
- 5 Spools cotton thread #50
- 1 Pkg. sewing needles, assorted
- 5 Yds. cotton towelling
- 12 Bars Lifebuoy soap
- 12 " laundry soap
- 3 Water pails

We do not appear to have received any letter from you with respect to the above supplies. I should like to know if you forwarded such a letter with the requisition.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
Manitowaning, Ontario.

September 3, 1940

Sir:

Replying to your letter No. 19-13-5 dated August 27th, regarding requisition for material for Birch Island School, no letter accompanied the requisition, as Mr. McGookin advised me, when he installed me in office, that a letter was not necessary, if the required information was given on the requisition.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

ORJ / JH
Ottawa,
September 7, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant the Department considers that a letter should be forwarded with each requisition. The letter should explain the reason for requesting the purchase of the articles mentioned on the requisition.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 29th ultimo reads in part as follows:

"Birch Island School needs renovating and painting inside class room about $75.00."

I presume that the cost of the material will not exceed $50.00 and, therefore, you may make local purchase of the material required and have the work done as soon as the school closes for the summer holidays.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. C.R. Johnston,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.

July 14, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a requisition for material to paint and make some repairs to the exterior of Birch Island Indian Day School.

Since making up this requisition, I have received your reply in regard to painting etc.; of Wikwemikong, Buzwah and Kaboni Schools, and note that this will about exhaust the amount allowed for repairs to schools this season.

Birch Island School however, is very badly in need of paint on the outside and I would prefer to dispense with some of the other work than let this go another year; For instance the excavation of earth from the basement of Kaboni School and some of the interior painting in Wikwemikong School could well be left to a later date, as they are not so urgent.

For convenience I would prefer to purchase the painting material, glass, nails etc.; from C. W. Hinds of Manitowaning from whom I got the estimates. The lumber for repairs to entrance platform and steps would in all probability be purchased from L. A. Buck of Little Current.

It is proposed to use Indian labour, which is estimated at $75.00 and I would be pleased to receive an advance cheque for this amount to pay labour, if it is possible to procure the material.

If the staining of the roof of Wikwemikong and West Bay Schools is dispensed with, this would add considerable to the funds.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I am informed by the Bishop of Algoma that the building used by the Church of England for religious services at Birch Island on the Whitefish River Reserve, is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch. I was entirely unaware of this, but the chief of the reserve also advises me the building was erected a number of years ago by the Indian Department for school and church purposes.

I would judge it is some time since it was used for school purposes, and there are at the present time only two or three families in Birch Island, who are not of Roman Catholic faith.

The Bishop reports that the roof is leaking badly, and that some other repairs are badly needed, but at the present time, I have no personal knowledge of the extent of the repairs required. He also reports that the student Missionary, Mr. E. N. Clark, of Whitefish Falls, and some of the Indians are willing to help with the work at least, up to the point of keeping the rain out.

Before going into further details, I would appreciate advice, as to whether the Department would consider assuming any responsibility whatever for repairs to this building, and if not, would there be any objection to the Missionary and the Indians making any repairs they may care to make voluntarily.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

You will find enclosed requisition for supplies for use at Birch Island Indian Day School during the coming academic year.

The needs of this school have been carefully estimated, and the supplies asked for are all quite urgently needed. The teacher has asked for 1 studio couch with back and arms, complete as there is very little furniture in the residence of this school. Last year, the teacher raised funds locally to buy a dining room suite, and I think the couch should be supplied to make her more comfortable. The chalk asked for was omitted from the school material requisition, and I would prefer that it be shipped to Mrs. Henry Fox, teacher, Birch Island School, Whitefish Falls, Ontario.

I would recommend these supplies be all furnished at an early date.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, the Department approves purchase of the articles shown on the attached list, with the exception of the manual training supplies and the studio couch. This will involve an expenditure of $82. Regarding the studio couch, you might let me know the name and address of the firm from whom you secured the quotation of $57.50.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Canada.

I acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated August 10th, File No.19-13-5, pertaining to requisition for supplies for Birch Island School.

The quotation of $57.50 for studio couch was received from C. W. Hinds, Hardware Merchant, Manitowaning, for a Simmons Couch which he has in stock, and of a quality which is not obtainable from the manufacturer at the present time. It can be converted into a double bed, and has a compartment in the bottom for clothing. A cheaper article could no doubt be obtained from Eaton's or Simpo's, if considered advisable.

In regard to the manual training supplies for this school, it was proposed to get all sewing and knitting material for girls, and the teacher, Mrs. Rose Fox, is competent in teaching this work.

It would require quite an outlay for tools to carry out any woodwork for boys, as up to the present time, there has been no manual training for boys carried out at this school.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent

For about two years the pump at Birch Island School has been out of commission. I had made several previous attempts to have it repaired but none of the people contacted ever got around to attend to it.

While Mrs. Rose Fox was teacher, her husband attempted to do it himself but had no tools to lift the pipes which had come apart leaving a great length in the well.

Last October, Stewart and Joly, contractors of Little Current, undertook to remove the piping and were finally successful in doing so. Although this was an emergency job, it is costing considerably more than was anticipated — $42.51 to date and the installation of a new Beatty pump complete with plunger and a concrete pump base is estimated at an additional $50.30.

I would be pleased to have authority for purchase and installation of the new pump as it is very inconvenient without the water at this school.

C. R. Johnston,

Ottawa, May 27, 1948.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

BIRCH ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

TEACHER

Miss McGregor had just reported for duty on the day of my visit, May 10. She is an Indian girl with no teaching experience and I spent most of my visit in assisting her with the planning of her classroom work. There are 25 children in Grades 1 to 7 and Miss McGregor will have her hands full in keeping them occupied.

SCHOOL and TEACHERAGE

This school is about 20 years old but is still in very good condition. The classroom is bright and is heated from a stove. It is well located, with a nice playground, and is on the highway to Little Current from Espanola. It is close to the Birch Island station on the C.P.R. line.

The teacher's quarters are good, with two bedrooms upstairs, living room and kitchen downstairs. The quarters are stove-heated but there is a basement which could be used for a furnace.

General
BIRCH ISLAND INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

GENERAL

This could be a very good school as the children are bright and responsive. They speak English much better than elsewhere on the Island. Because of its accessible location, we should be able to interest a teacher in this position.

Water is from a pump in the kitchen and although no hydro is available, it will eventually come along the highway.

My recommendations for this school are:

1. The placing of a new roof.
2. The building of a new woodshed.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education

November 12, 1942

Sir:-

You will find enclosed herewith a requisition for supplies from Miss Carmel Cahill, teacher, Birch Island Indian Day School.

These articles are all badly needed, but I wish to refer particularly to the cook stove, which is a very old dilapidated affair. The one I have listed on the requisition is a Findlay Oval with copper reservoir, similar to the one purchased for Kaboni School last year, except that due to war restrictions it is not possible now to get the warming closet.

C. W. Hinds of Manitowaning has this one in stock and the price quoted covers delivery charges. These ranges have an excellent reputation, and I can strongly recommend it. The cistern pump head has been broken and out of commission for some time. I have tried to make some repairs, but so far have been unsuccessful. As the cost is only $5.00, I would recommend getting a new pump.

The linoleum on the kitchen and living room floor is worn out in several places. It is all the same pattern, and it is proposed to get a new rug for the kitchen floor, and use the best parts of the old one to replace worn places in the living room.

There is no axe, saw or hammer at the school; and several of the door locks are out of commission.

I would recommend these articles be purchased locally.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following observations concerning the teachers of the Day Schools under my care, at Basawah, Wikwemikong, South Bay, West Bay, Sheeshewaning, and through the travelling missionary Rev. J.R. Richard, at Mississauga, Serpent River (Cutler), and White Fish Lake. Upon me falls the very difficult task of finding suitable teachers for these schools. I can but seldom secure competent persons, and they do not stay a sufficient length of time to improve the pupils, because the salary paid is too small, and most of these places too much isolated. I have often expressed my opinion to your Department and to the Inspectors, that if the salary of teachers in those schools would be raised to the sum of $300 all around, at least as a trial, I could secure the services of certificated teachers, and these schools might rise to a proper efficiency.

On the 21st of April last I was advised by your Department that "The whole question of school management would be dealt with by the Superintendent General at the earliest possible date". Now is the proper time for hiring teachers. There is a vacancy at West Bay, Sheeshewaning, and White Fish Lake. The Indians at South Bay complain that their teacher Mrs. C.S. Ainscough does not do justice to her work, and ask for a competent male teacher, who cannot be found for $300. I am offered the services of young men and ladies who might do creditable work, but they have no special preparation for teaching school and have no certificate. If the salaries paid heretofore remain the same, I will have to propose them to your approval for want of more competent persons.

Please advise me as soon as possible of the course to follow.

Your obedient Servant

Rev. J. Pequin, S.J.

OTTAWA, 9th September, 1904:

The Acting Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Agent Sims has reported the resignation of Father Kehmstedt, teacher of the Buzwah school and states that Father Paquin wishes the salary allowed for this school to be used for the tuition of five pupils from the Buzwah settlement at the Wikwemikong, paying at the usual per capita rate of $60.00.

I may state that the average attendance at the Buzwah school for the past year was exactly five and that it has never exceeded that number for a good many years. It would therefore be to the advantage of the children of that section to give them the benefit of the industrial school training at Wikwemikong and it would be an actual saving to the Department as it would not be called upon to provide fuel and other contingencies.

The Accountant informs me that there would be no objection to making this change and the Wikwemikong school has ample accommodation for the extra pupils. I would therefore recommend that you approve of Father Paquin's suggestion.

Sir:

I have the honor to report that the Indian families living in the vicinity of Buzwah School are anxious that the Department would reopen their school at an early date. There are sixteen families with about twenty-five children of school age, six to fifteen; even if twenty attended it would be a good school.

I went and examined the old school building and I find that it would cost from $100.00 to $125.00 to repair the school.

It requires a new roof, shingled, gables repaired, new floor, ceiling repaired, plastered inside and out, whitewashed, with some other minor repairs including the closets. I have the honor to report that I consider Miss Dodd is not performing her duties as teacher at Buswah satisfactorily, and the children are not getting justice, as she has only taught 54 days since the midsummer holidays, and the school has not yet opened since the Christmas holidays.

The Reverend Father Artus, Missionary at Wikwemikong, and the Indians in general have been complaining of the way Miss Dodd is attending to her duties and have asked me to recommend to the Department that she be asked to resign at Easter.

I understand that she has not been well since the New Year and was not able to teach, but I enquired from Dr. Shaw today in connection with her health and he informed me that she could of taught all last week, as he considered that she was quite well enough.

I quite understand that Miss Dodd is not a very strong person, and have overlooked a great many little complaints from the Indians on that account, but as she appears now to be losing all interest in the school, and the children not getting justice, I have to recommend to the Department that she be asked to resign.

Sir,

A petition has been forwarded by Rev. Father Artus from the Indians of the Buzwah Band in which they express an earnest desire to retain the services of Miss Clara King as teacher of the Buzwah Indian Day School during the next school year beginning September 1, 1922.

It is hoped to have the work on the new building commence very shortly. Plans have already been prepared and tenders are now being called for.

Sir:

I have the honour to report to the effect that the teachers in charge of Bazwah and both classrooms of Wikwemikong Schools ceased teaching on Tuesday evening the 30th ultimo and left Wednesday morning as I presume on a holiday.

No notice was given this office of their intention of closing these Schools; in fact I did not know that the Schools were closed until some of the Indian parents made enquiries as to the reason why these Schools were not open.

The fact of Indian Schools being closed during regular teaching days without a just cause has a tendency to make the Indian Parents careless in sending their children to school regularly. These Schools should be kept open during regular teaching periods and closed during authorized holidays.

Terrified by the sudden appearance of a stranger in the bedroom in which she was sleeping, the public school teacher at the Indian School at Boswah received serious injuries to the back when she jumped through the window to elude her assailant. The intrusion took place early Friday morning. The victim has been confined to bed under the doctor's care during the past week.

Joe Mandamin, an Indian resident of the Wikwemikong Reserve, is being held pending trial. Evidence has shown he could not give a satisfactory account of his whereabouts that night and early the next morning sought to hire a car to take him out of the district at once.

It is not known how the intruder gained admission to the house, but the assault was planned beforehand and information obtained regarding the layout of the house. A woollen dress and a towel wrapped about the head of the intruder were used as a disguise and because of this identification has not been readily obtained. The girl was suddenly awakened by the touch of the intruder and by putting up a ferocious fight by clawing at his face freed herself. The open window provided the only means of escape at the moment to the terrified girl. The prisoner charged with the crime has served prison terms on two other occasions.
Halfbreed Sentenced Five Years and Lashes

Convicted of House-breaking and Assault.

GORE BAY, Ont., July 9.—Convinced of house-breaking and indecent assault, Joe Mindamin, halfbreed, was sentenced to five years in Port Arthur penitentiary and 20 lashes in police court here yesterday.

Ida Brown, Venosta, Que., who teaches school at Mani- toulin Island, is in hospital suffering from spine injuries as a result of the assault. She was sleeping in her room in the school building when she awoke to find a man in the room wearing a light coloured dress. When he attacked her, she stuck her fingers into his face and jumped 16 feet from a window to the ground. Miss Brown then made her way to a neighbor's house where she collapsed.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of July 11th with reference to accident of Miss Ida Brown.

She has a crushed fracture of the body of her second lumbar vertebrae with but little deformity at present. There are no neurological symptoms, that is she has no anaesthesia of skin, no loss of motor power in her limbs. She has some incontinence of urine but it seems to be improving and will likely disappear.

I immediately got in touch with Dr. W.E. Gallie of Toronto regarding treatment for her. Dr. Gallie is one of the outstanding men on this continent for such type of cases. He advised me to have her in bed in hospital for at least 2 months.

I think the girl has been very fortunate in that she has no neurological symptoms and because of this fact is likely to have little if any permanent disability.

If there is anything further you wish please advise me.

Yours very truly,

Dr. H.H. Harvie.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that an unfortunate event took place at the Buzwah Indian Day School on Saturday morning the 27th ultimo. Miss Brown, the teacher in charge, had closed the class room the evening before for the purpose of visiting Ottawa and her intention to leave for her home near Ottawa the following morning, but on the morning she proposed to leave, at an early hour, an Indian by means of a skeleton key entered her dwelling and during her excitement she jumped from the upstairs bedroom window a distance of 10 feet or more, and by so doing injured her back.

An X-Ray of the injury shows a fracture of a small bone in her back, and to assure complete recovery and be able to resume her duties by the first of September next, the Doctor in charge at Espanola hospital, where she is at present, has advised her to remain quietly in the hospital until that time; otherwise, she would have to be placed in a cast which she dreads.

On account of financial difficulty she cannot afford to stay in the hospital, as it would appear that her earnings in the past has gone towards the support of other members in the family, and has make request of me to take the matter up with the Department in order to ascertain whether, or not, the Department would be willing to give some assistance in the way of paying the hospital expense.

At present her mother is with her at Espanola and will remain there until an answer is received from the Department as to whether, or not, assistance will be granted in paying the hospital expense. If the Department will not assist the mother will be forced to make some arrangement for the removal of the girl to her home.

This matter would of been reported to the Department at an earlier date if I had known the condition of Miss Brown. I did not find out her exact condition until I made a trip to Espanola yesterday, Sunday, and found her in the above circumstances.

Under the above circumstances as to where and the way this accident took place, and taking into consideration the financial circumstances of this unfortunate girl I would most respectfully recommend that her hospital expenses be paid. The Department might wire Miss Brown direct to Espanola in order to save time in letting the mother know whether, or not, the girl will have to be taken home.

I might also say for the information of the Department that the Indian implicated in this case was given a sentence of five years in Kingston penitentiary with twenty strokes of lash.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Indian Agent,
Ottawa, Ont.

She partially recognized the Indian by his shoes and trousers.

After her fall she was able to drag herself to an Indian house and sent for Dr. Shaw. She asked to be brought to Little Current.

Dear Mr. Gallagher:

I wish to bring to your attention the case of Joe Mandamin, of Wikwemikong, Ont., 36 year old ward of this Department. On the 8th instant, this Indian was sentenced, in police court at Gore Bay, to 5 years in Portsmouth Penitentiary and 20 lashes. He had been convicted of housebreaking and indecent assault.

It appears that, about 2 A.M., of the 27th ultimo, Mandamin, using a skeleton key, entered the residence of Miss Ida Brown, teacher of the Buswah Indian Day School, which is situated between Wikwemikong and Manitowaning. A Canadian Press dispatch, printed in Ottawa papers of the 10th instant, reads in part as follows: "She was sleeping in her room in the school building, when she awoke to find a man in the room, wearing a light coloured dress. When he attacked her, she stuck her fingers in his eyes and jumped 16 feet from a window to the ground." Miss Brown suffered an injury to her spine and is now resting in hospital at Espanola at departmental expense. She wishes to return to her school in September, and her medical attendant believes she will be recovered by that time.

This Department does not in any way condone the action of Joe Mandamin; but, recently, there has come to my attention information that, I believe, should be placed before your Branch. Joe's parents, when writing to the Department for advice and help, state: "By reports, Joe and Miss Brown were out driving and went to dances together, and we don't think he would assault her". Evidence that Joe was well known to Miss Brown has been given to the Superintendent of Indian Education by the

- teacher of

M. F. Gallagher, Esq.,
Chief of Clemency Branch,
Dept. of Justice,
Ottawa, Ont.
teacher of the Kaboni Indian School, which is 4 miles from Buzwah. The parish priest at Wikwemikong has written in part as follows: "Without blaming her (Miss Brown), people say that she had given encouragement to the man... at least on evenings walking out with him."

It has also been reported to the Department that Joe Mandamin was sub-normal and, in addition, had been drinking the night of the offence. Rev. Father E. A. Papineau, S. J., of Little Current, has written that Miss Brown gave him the declaration which was used at the trial after considerable persuasion. He writes that the teacher, when half awake, pushed Mandamin away without his offering much resistance, raised the window blind, opened the window and jumped to the ground.

It is probable that Miss Brown's injury and Mandamin's early record - convictions for theft and forgery - were partly responsible for the stiff sentence. The man's acquaintancehip for the teacher, his ridiculous efforts at disguise and his lack of violence - taken together - suggest an unusual attitude of mind.

Some of the facts may not have been brought out at the trial, and I write to suggest that your Department give consideration to remission of the lashes.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Miss Brown:

Your sister has left with me your letter of the 27th ultimo, and I note you are doubtful if you will be able to commence teaching on the first of September. I believe you are just a little discouraged from your enforced stay in bed, and I am still hopeful that Dr. Harvie's first estimate of two months will be quite accurate.

I have been in touch with a few teachers in the past, since receiving your letter, and I have secured the services of one who will take, for a few weeks or months, whatever position we hold for you. So, you do not need to worry about work. It will be ready for you as soon as you are ready for it.

The question now to be decided is what school would be the best in your case. The Secretary wrote you on the 26th ultimo, suggesting the Lower French River Indian Day School, near Pickerel, Ont. This was my first suggestion, but I am still looking for something still better from the standpoint of living conditions. At very few of our Catholic Indian day schools in the East do two or more teachers live together. Further, I know of no single roomed school where the teacher can board in a white home. Perhaps the nicest place for you would be at St. Regis, where four teachers live together. Your sister has taught there and you will know something of conditions. The difficulty will be to create a vacancy for you there,

making enquiries to this end now.

I thank you for your letter No. 19-1-1.

I have communicated to Miss Brown these reasons why I believe it to be better for her to be transferred to another school, in which case we desire very much to see Miss Stella King appointed for Patmar.

As for her assistant's case, though I was not present at the trial, I knew that there had been no other eye-witnesses than the young woman herself, that from her I learned (before the trial) that the man had a kind of a veil around his head... and that he put out the lamp as soon as he entered the room that then was in darkness... How then could this man be recognized with certainty? - Miss Brown, when I went to see her on the morning following the deed in question, she did not know who it was... Only when the name of the man arrested was suggested to her by Mr. P. Lewis, she said it must be he. I have no doubt that, while she said so, she believed it. But as a fact, could not her believing it be a mistake? It seems to me, that there was and there could be no doubt.

And I remember very well, first of all, that at one of the similar cases where I had to be a short while before, the crown attorney told me that the woman's declaration is not accepted as evidence unless there is another witness,... and secondly, that I heard the magistrate in his speech to the
...insisting that should there remain any doubt in their mind, the accused should be given the benefit of it and be discharged. And so it happened twice when the girls victims were Indian women.

This may help the Indian Department's officers in their efforts to have the case reconsidered.

October 23, 1931.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

I have to report concerning the latest developments in the case of Miss Ida Brown, formerly employed as teacher at the Buxah Indian Day School. You will remember that Miss Brown was injured when she jumped from the upstairs window of the residence at the school, on June 27th, when an Indian attacked her. With your concurrence, the Department promised to pay the hospital and medical expenses while she was recovering from a fractured spine.

On October 14th, after Miss Brown had been in Espanola Hospital for 3½ months, the medical officer there reported that "her progress was slower than hoped for last month and it was necessary to prolong her time in bed to three months. She has, however, been able to sit out of bed the last two days with a spine splint and is progressing well now. I expect she will be able to leave the hospital in the course of another one or two weeks and probably resume her duties some time next month". Two days later, the authorities at the hospital telegraphed that Miss Brown had "developed delusions of persecution and required restraint. She has fear of remaining in hospital, is now able to walk with back splint. Advise transferring her home under escort". After getting in touch with her parents at Venosta, Que., the Department authorized an escort to her home.

Miss Brown left Espanola on Saturday the 17th instant, in charge of Miss Paradis, senior nurse of the Espanola Hospital - a very competent person. There was quite a bit of difficulty on the train and when they arrived in Ottawa, early Sunday morning, the nurse thought it better to have the girl rest at Water Street Hospital for the day. Miss Brown is still suffering from delusions concerning persecution and it was necessary to telephone to her mother to come to Ottawa. The mother and brother had a rather good effect on the patient and the latter slept all night. I engaged a special nurse, Miss Quinn, for the day, to relieve Nurse Paradis, and for that night and the ensuing week, a Nurse Villeneuve, who was to accompany Miss Brown to her home at Venosta and was to receive $7.00 a day for her services. Monday morning, the condition of Miss Brown was such that it was considered advisable to send her home by car, and I engaged a Bank Street heated taxi, at a cost of $11.00, for the trip. The patient
was accompanied by her mother, Nurse Villeneuve, who was to stay at Venosta the week, and Nurse Paradis from Espanola. I saw that Miss Brown was examined by the general Hospital House Surgeons before discharge. It was felt by all that had been associated with the case, including Dr. Stone, our Director of Medical Services, with whom I had been in close touch in the matter, that a few days at home might make a wonderful difference in her mental condition. I advised the mother and Nurse Villeneuve to get in touch with the family physician - Dr. Desjardins, of Gracefield - if Miss Brown did not improve.

It appears that when the patient reached the home there was a marked improvement for the rest of the day. She walked around the house and yard and chatted freely with the members of the family also ate at the dining room table. From Tuesday until the present time, however, there was a serious setback, as the patient would no longer take nourishment of any kind and would not converse with even her own people. The brother drove to Ottawa with a letter from Nurse Villeneuve, asking for further advice and urging immediate attention. Dr. Desjardins recommended immediate removal to an institution, but the mother was insisting on an examination by a neurologist.

Dr. Stone made enquiries as to the provincial responsibility in case institutional care was needed and we were of the opinion that it might be advisable to have the matter decided in Quebec. With your concurrence, Dr. C. R. Graham, of this city, a psychiatrist of much experience and well known to Dr. Stone, was engaged, so that the Department would have a report on Miss Brown's condition. He, Dr. Stone and myself motored to Venosta last evening, and, after examining Miss Brown, he recommended immediate removal to a proper institution. Dr. Desjardins, the family physician, was also present, and today the family made arrangements to take her to the asylum at Longue Pointe, a few miles east of Montreal. With reference to the matters discussed in this case, I clearly explained to Mr. Brown, in the presence of Doctors Stone and Desjardins, that the Department could accept no further responsibility. We will have presented to us the account of the Espanola Hospital, which will include Nurse Paradis' expenses - a total of approximately $350.00; $4.00 or $5.00 for Special Nurse Quinn; a like amount from the Water Street Hospital: $11.00 from the Bank Street Taxi: Dr. Graham's fee and approximately $50.00 for the services and expenses of Nurse Villeneuve. Mr. Brown asked me this morning if we would pay all or part of the cost of sending the patient to Longue Pointe by car to Ottawa, as there was an unfortunate misunderstanding regarding the train service this morning, and they had to wait over 6 hours. I regretted that the Department could give no further help.

I informed Mr. Brown that his sister had our cheque for $255 which, I understand, is not yet cashed.
and that his sister, in her right mind, would want it expended freely in the effort for her recovery. I regret that he did not appear particularly satisfied with all we have done for Miss Brown. He remarked that there was approximately $55 in money and $35 worth of clothing lost while his sister was at Espanola Hospital. There may be a misunderstanding in this connection, however; but I promised to write to the hospital with a view to ascertaining if she had any property there.

When the accounts in connection with Miss Brown's care are to hand, it will be necessary to have them taxed by the Department of Health, as directed by Treasury Board Minute of June 3, 1930, a copy of which is hereunder.

Dear Sir:

I had prepared a report for you this morning but on speaking to Miss Paradis who returned at noon today, I will omit much of what I had intended to say since she and Mr. Ferrier have discussed the case and covered much of the ground. As far as what Miss Paradis reported to Mr. Ferrier I need only say that Miss Paradis has had very close contact with the patient throughout her stay here and her report is absolutely reliable.

When Miss Brown came to us on July the second I noticed from the first that she was slightly "odd". Not having known her before, and since the experience she had just had was sufficient to shake anyone's nervous stability I expected that this would clear with rest and time. Since then she has taken little interest in the things which patients usually welcome to help occupy their minds when confined to bed. In view of the distance she was from home special efforts have been made to entertain her in the way of providing books magazines etc., supplying her room with flowers and a number of visitors have been arranged. To all this she showed only an extreme apathy. As the third month of her stay in bed came she showed no desire to get up and complained of much pain in her back, which, however, vanished in a few minutes on moving her to a different room. When I started getting her out of bed about the sixth of this month she was very disinclined to do so though her back appeared quite strong and certainly in
Dr. H. H. Harvie
Esquimalt, Ont.

the past few days she has shown considerable strength. The X-Rays indicate the expected result in consolidation of the fracture. Miss Paradis has reported to Mr. Ferrier her sudden change mentally, starting on Oct. 14th with restlessness and lack of cooperation, on the 15th with marked apprehension for her safety, and on the 16th with violent refusal to be without at least two people with her at night, refusal to go to bed etcetera, and varying from refusal to attempts to resist restraint and escape form the hospital. On the afternoon of the 16 and on the 17th she was absolutely irrational.

Dr. Harvie, acting with the advice of Dr. Gallie of Toronto who examined her X-Ray films, considered the average time for a case of this sort before being able to walk should be about two months. She has had over three months in bed and her X-Ray films indicate good consolidation. I believe it is reasonably safe to allow her to be on her feet without support now. With her mental condition such as it is it is impossible to determine if she is having any pain or indication of strain or not.

It is extremely unfortunate that this mental condition should intervene at this point in her convalescence from her back condition. While it was noticeable that her apathy was not clearing as time went on, there was no warning of the onset of this sudden acute mental breakdown or I would have sent her home on a stretcher before it occurred. There has been nothing in her surroundings here to cause a mental change at this time. If her mental aberration had been due to the accident and its accompanying circumstances one would expect it to be decreasing rather than
increasing and to have been different from what it has been.

I shall be glad to know of her final disposition and to be of any assistance to you possible.

Yours truly,

Dr. B.H. Berry.

October 23rd, 1931.

Doctor Stone:

In accordance with your request I visited Miss Ida Brown at her home in Venosta, P.Q., in company with Dr. Desjardins, of Gracefield. The patient refused to co-operate in any way with the examination and actively resisted to such an extent that a proper complete neurological examination was impossible, but sufficient information was obtained to come to a fair estimate of her condition and to arrive at a definite diagnosis as to her mental disorder. I believe this young woman is suffering from Dementia Praecox of the catatonic type. As far as I could estimate I do not think she has any organic lesion of the spinal cord, and I do not believe that she is pregnant although time will tell in both these respects. My diagnosis of Dementia Praecox would of necessity exclude recent shock as a cause of the disease because to quote Dawson's extract from Hoeh "like the poet Dementia Praecox is born, not made". Also from the available information received from available sources, the patient would appear to have been naturally of a quiet, shy, retiring disposition, while possessing considerable intellectual ability; quite a usual type of pre-dementia praecox personality. I append herewith a summary of my examination of Miss Brown's mental condition:

General condition: The patient is lying quietly in bed, clad in night robe, her hair rather disordered, bed clothes thrown partially aside. She has a vacant staring expression, rolls her head from side to side and sucks and bites her lips. The legs are stretched out rigidly and the arms flexed on the chest. The patient appears to be a well nourished female about 20 years of age. She actively resists any attempt at examination.

Physical abnormalities: Knee jerks and pupillary reflexes about normal. Other reflexes could not be examined on account of patients resistance. No pigmentation of breasts, no distention of veins of the legs, bladder apparently contains some urine, and Dr. Desjardins could not feel any abnormal tumour in the abdomen, bowels have been confined for about six days inspite of enemata, tongue dry, glazed and cracked, lips covered with sordes.

Consciousness: The patient refused to talk, which made it very .......
difficult to learn her mental processes. She took little or no interest in her surroundings, her attention was easily attracted by a touch, but was only retained long enough to fight off the examiner, the mind was dissociated to a marked degree from its environment and was occupied by a phantasy of some kind. This self isolation was the most conspicuous symptom in her condition.

Cognition: Sensations of touch, sight and hearing were not impaired but no hallucinations in either sphere were shown during examination. Somatic hallucinations may be present however and be related to her delusion. Her conversation is limited to a few short sentences, related to matters intimately connected with herself: "Get away, don't touch me, Mother don't leave me, He is coming again" being the sum total of her conversation for the greater part of the day. This suggests that there is a paucity of ideas.

Orientation: She recognized her mother and brother and realized that the Doctors and Nurse are strangers. Also evidently knows their sex. Knowledge of time or place could not be estimated, but she knew she was at home when brought in from the hospital and for some hours was much brighter and talked.

Delusions: She informed Miss Villeneuve, the Nurse, that she was going to have a baby and asked her to do something to get rid of it. She is constantly rubbing at her abdomen.

Conation: Her conduct showed negativism, her movements were purposeful, sudden, energetic and directed against the suggestion and actions of the examiner. She refused to speak, refused to eat or drink for 48 hours, resisted the actions of the bowels for about six days and the other calls of nature entirely until catheterized after which she yielded in that respect, she constantly stared at the ceiling and rolled her head from side to side, grimaced, and bit her lips, her conversation when she did speak was sharp, short and to the point "Don't touch me, get away".

Affection: Her face was expressionless and emotional control was weak. An outburst of angry words and a blow were the immediate response to an attempt to feel her pulse. The only sign of affection was her request to her mother not to leave her.
Dr. W. Harvie
Espanola, Ont.

Memorandum:

I understand that an Order in Council, dated July 23, 1906, rules that accounts for medical and hospital expenses of government employees who have been injured in the performance of duty should be passed by the Treasury Board before payment. The Department now wishes to meet such costs in the case of Miss Ida Brown, teacher of the Buzwah Indian Day School, Manitoulin Island, who, on the night of June 25th, last, was assaulted by an Indian who broke into her residence on the reserve. Dear Mrs. Morris:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to your sister Ida, formerly teacher at the Buzwah Indian Day School, and I can quite understand that you are very much upset. I saw your sister when she was in Ottawa, on her way home, and, in reply to your question, I may say she recognized me, though she was certainly not in a normal condition.

The Department's information is as follows:
On October 16th, the medical officer of the Espanola Hospital reported that Ida was now sitting out of bed with a spine splint and was progressing well. Two days later, however, they telegraphed to us that she had developed delusions of persecution and required restraint. It appeared that Ida had fear of remaining in hospital, and, as she was able to walk with a back splint and the doctors so recommended the action, she was escorted to her home in Venosta. For three days, she rested on Monday, October 18th, and until Monday morning at the General Hospital, Water Street, Ottawa. I was called there and your sister chatted with me but was still suffering from her delusion. It was necessary to get your mother and your brother to come to Ottawa to try to reassure her. Your mother stayed over night and returned with Ida by taxi to Venosta on Monday morning, and for the rest of the day there was a marked improvement in her mental condition. However, on Tuesday, October 20th, there was a serious setback, as she would not take nourishment of any kind and would not talk to her mother or brother. Dr. Desjardins, of Gracefield, recommended immediate removal to an institution, where she could be properly cared for, but your mother wanted her examined by an expert on mental disorders. The Department secured the services of an experienced psychiatrist who saw your sister at Venosta and advised your brother to agree to the suggestion of Dr. Desjardins. Ida was then sent to an institution at Longue Pointe, just a few miles east of Montreal. I have not had any information direct from Longue Pointe concerning her present condition.

So that you will know that the Department has taken as much interest in your sister's case as possible.

Sirs:

Re: Ida Brown - your file

We are writing with reference to a conversation the writer had with you and other officers of the Department some considerable time ago on the above subject. Your file will no doubt familiarize you with the facts of the case which are, briefly, these -

Miss Brown was a teacher in the employ of the Department at an Indian School at or near Espanola, Ontario. In the summer of 1931 (your file will no doubt acquaint you with the relevant dates) an Indian broke into Miss Brown's room in the evening, which so frightened our client that she jumped out of the second story window, a distance of twelve feet from the ground, suffering serious injuries. She was admitted to Espanola Hospital and all her expenses while she remained in that institution were borne by the Department of Indian Affairs, in addition to certain other incidental expenses.

As a result of her injuries and the shock, Miss Brown suffered a temporary mental derangement which necessitated constant care and medical attention, after she left Espanola, which culminated in her being sent to an institution in Montreal, the St. Jean-De-Dieu Hospital at St. Gemelin, Quebec.
The Department has not undertaken any further responsibility in the matter and the expenses incurred subsequent to Miss Brown's leaving Espanola have not been paid. The writer spoke to Dr. D.C. Scott about a year ago and the latter said that the Department did not consider itself to be liable in any way.

I am writing at the present time to ascertain if the Department, in view of subsequent developments, would reconsider the case. When the officers of the Department were last interviewed, Miss Brown was still a patient in the asylum in Quebec. It did not appear at that time that she was making any progress, and the writer is of the opinion that the possibility and likelihood of her permanent insanity weighed considerably with the officials' refusal to render further aid; because had they done so at that juncture it might have been construed as an admission of legal liability.

Miss Brown has since completely recovered and is now working in a Montreal Department store. The situation has thus become materially altered. She is of the opinion that as the total expenses are now known and as there will be no further or additional expenses, the danger of admitting liability for future expenses does not exist.

This is a particularly sad case and the Department cannot help but sympathize with our client in the serious injuries that she has suffered. Her expenses and disbursements are small and it is thought that it might be recommended that they be borne by the Department and that a release of all future claims be executed by our client in favour of the Crown. A statement of these expenses is attached hereto, for your consideration.

We wish to make it clear that we are not raising the question of any legal liability on the part of the Crown, but merely as extenuating circumstances to be considered we give you the following -

1. The Department paid our client's hospital and medical bills at Espanola and our client has a statement to the Doctor at Espanola, signed by the Secretary, Mr. A.D. McKenzie, at the time, from which we quote the following:
"In view of your report and recommendation and letter from Miss Ida Brown, Department will be responsible for hospital and medical expenses in her case. Please inform her and state Department hopes she will be completely recovered in time to return to her school at Burwash in September."

2. The late Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education, in his letter to our client dated August 1st, 1931, says in part as follows -

"As I explained to Mrs. Morris the Department cannot consider compensation if your disability proves temporary, but we will continue to pay your hospital and medical costs."

3. Though we have not seen Dr. Harvie's detailed report, we conclude from a communication that we have received from Dr. B. H. Berry, Dr. Harvie's assistant, that Miss Brown's mental derangement was due directly to the accident, and the result of other inquiries convince us that there was no insanity in the Brown family.

We would earnestly request, therefore, that this case be reconsidered and that the final expenses of this unfortunate girl be taken care of and that she provide the Crown with a complete release in return therefor. If you wish to discuss this matter further, the writer will be pleased to call at your office at any time that is convenient to you.

We have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient Servants,

Ottawa, June 6, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing the resignation of Stella R. King as teacher of the Buswah Indian Day School, to take effect at the end of the present school year. Miss King's resignation is accepted.

I have to inform you that the Department is approving of the appointment of Christine Wakegijig as teacher for the next school year, provided she obtains her second class interim certificate from the North Bay Normal School at the end of this term. The salary allowed Miss Wakegijig will be at the same rate as was paid Miss King, viz.: $80 per teaching month.

After you are assured that Miss Wakegijig has been successful in her examinations, you may advise her of her appointment as teacher of the Buswah School and arrange with her to begin duties on September third, next, the date the schools re-open after the summer holidays. It is noted that Rev. Father Belanger approves of her appointment.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

Replying to Official Letter No. 151719/1 of February, 28th, last, regarding repairs to the Buzwah School. I have the honor to report that I have carefully gone into this matter and find that the School needs the following repairs: The roof should be taken off and the walls raised at least ten inches and a new roof put on, a new belfry put on, new ceiling, new door, new window, new floor, plastered inside and out, porch repaired, chimney built, whitewashed inside and out, and the closets repaired. I have had a contractor, Mr Neil McMarten, look over this work and he has agreed to do all the above repairs for $192.50.

In regard to the teacher I beg to say that there is no suitable lodging place nor house that they could get and it will be necessary to build a house for them. I have had Mr McMarten make an estimate on a building 16 x 22 feet two story with an addition 16 x 18 feet one story. He has agreed to build this complete, with cellar under kitchen for $1250.00.

There could be a smaller building erected say 16 x 22 feet, one story, with stone foundation, no cellar, which would give two rooms for about the cost of $500.00.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont..
If the School was repaired and a teachers dwelling erected separate, the cost of those would go a long way in paying for a new School with teachers residence attached. On examination of the old school since the snow went away I find it is only built on posts, and will only do, if repaired, five or six years at the outside.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 29, 1913.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant in reference to the provision of school accommodation at Nuzwah.

In reply I beg to say that the contents of your letter have been noted. The Department is not prepared at the present time to expend an amount such as suggested for the erection of a teacher's residence. If a new building is necessary the Department wishes to have your opinion as to whether it would not be preferable to erect a school-house and remodel the existing building for a teacher's residence, such as was done at Wikwemikongising. The Department has made no special provision for new buildings at this point this year, but at a later date might be able to find funds if decided to build, and has at present a plan of a school-house for twenty-five pupils that would meet the requirements here.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Extract from Agent's Monthly Report on the Buzwah Indian Day School for the month of April, 1914.

Original on File 151719-7.

The teacher reports to me that if there is not a dwelling secured more convenient to the school for the next year she will resign as she thinks it is too far from the school. I have made enquiries and cannot get a building any more convenient. The only remedy would be to build a new school and have a residence attached or use the old place for a residence. The Indians are settling on farms and it will only be another year and the present school will be too small to accommodate all the pupils, as at present the school is full and cannot hold any more seats.

(Sgd.) W. McLeod.
Indian Agent
Ottawa, May 8, 1914.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your report on the Buzwah School for the month of April, last.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to put up a new school building at Buzwah with accommodation for the teacher this year. The present teacher's residence is not too far from the school, the only inconveniences being the steep hill and the trouble in securing water. The Department would like to know whether you think it would be possible to obtain water nearer than the lake by sinking a well and, if so, what it would cost.

I may add that the Department would like to retain Miss Dodd's services and is only awaiting the inspector's report to consider her application for an increase in salary.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Wm. McLeod, Esq.,

OTTAWA, February 27th, 1922.

Sir,

The Department has received a communication from Miss Clara A. King, teacher of the Buswah Indian day school, drawing attention to the condition of the present school building, and requesting that steps be taken as soon as possible to erect a new building with accommodation for the teacher. She states that the Indians are anxious to have their children attend school and are interested in their progress, but that the present building is in such a dilapidated condition that it is not fit to be used for school purposes.

In this connection I may say that the Department will not have any funds available out of the appropriation for the new school year to erect a building at this point. The Manitoulin Island Unceded Band has over $40,000 in its trust funds to the credit of its capital account, and it may be that the Indians would agree by resolution of the Band in council to provide sufficient funds to erect a new building. It would require at least $5,000 for the purpose of erecting a combined school and teacher's living quarters.

I will be pleased if you will take this matter up with the Band, impress upon them the necessity for a new school building and endeavour to have them pass a resolution setting aside the money necessary from their capital account to erect this building. You inform the Band that the Department is quite unable to assist them in providing any grant of money towards putting up a suitable building, and that, if they desire that the work of putting up the building should be undertaken this coming summer, they will have to provide the necessary funds.

You should give this matter your early attention, and have the matter placed before the council at the next meeting, and inform the Department as to the decision arrived at.

Miss King is being informed that the matter of erecting a new building has been referred to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

MEMORANDUM.

I beg to report that on the 4th inst., I made an inspection of the new Buzwah combined day school and teachers' residence which has just been completed by Mr. George Strain of Gore Bay, Ont.

In general, the outside of the building presents a good appearance and the materials and workmanship are in accordance with the plans and specifications, with a few exceptions. The interior of the building in many cases is not finished according to the plans and specifications and a great deal of the workmanship was very carelessly performed. After discussing the question of the unsatisfactory work with Mr. Strain, he agreed to do what was necessary to finish the building in a proper manner, and remedy the faulty work. I am of the opinion that the faulty work was done by Mr. Strain through ignorance of good construction on his part and not from a desire to evade the plans and specifications.

If the work as enumerated below is carried out to the satisfaction of Agent Lewis, I would recommend that Mr. Strain be paid the balance due him on his contract. I may say that the building is well located and no trouble should be experienced in keeping the same perfectly dry.

The following is a list of the matters that will have to be attended to in order to remedy the faulty work, and Mr. Strain promised to have these items attended to. These items were indicated in the plans and specifications, but were not carried out as they should have been by the Contractor.

- Basement walls to be beam filled,
- Herring-boned bridging to be provided in floor joist in basement.
- Hardwood flooring to be laid on the first floor.
- Faulty material in wainscoting of class room to be removed and good material installed in its place.
- Storm windows to be properly fitted.
- Lifts and fasts to be put on all windows.
Outside steps and porches to be rebuilt in accordance with the specifications.
The interior wood work is exceedingly rough. The same shall have to be sand-papered and varnished as specified.

CEILING OF CLASS ROOM. The shiplap that was specified to be laid under the V joint finish was omitted. It will therefore be necessary to lay over the top of the existing V joint, another thickness of V joint at right angles to that already in place.

I am today writing a letter confirming these instructions, for the Secretary's signature.

ARCHITECT.
J. D. McLean,

Extract from Inspector's Report on the BUZWAH School

May 23, 1923.

The accompanying points concerning the new building are not given except in friendly criticism for your consideration.

(1)- All in very good shape. The school should be painted on the exterior again.

(2)- About two inches of water entered the cellar. The school is so situated on a hill that it could be very easily drained.

(3)- Cistern froze up in winter. It appears that no vegetables can be kept in the cellar during the winter. Potatoes, onions and carrots which the teacher had stored for use froze in the cellar.

(4)- There is no well for drinking water. At present it is obtained from a farmer near by. All water for cooking, etc., has to be brought in this way.

(5)- For some reason or other the one stove in the teacher's rooms heated only the kitchen.

// Provision should be made for next winter's wood.

J. M. Bennet,
Insp.
Ottawa, June 1, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Buswah Indian Day School, states that while the school building is in very good condition, water entered the cellar. He says that drainage could be very easily carried out. He further states that frost entered the cellar and it was impossible to store vegetables during last winter. He also reports that a well should be dug, to provide water for drinking and cooking purposes.

I shall be pleased if you will furnish a report regarding the above and state what you would advise having done in each case, as well as the probable cost of any work recommended by you.

The Inspector further recommends that provision be made in due time for the supplying of next winter's wood, in order that it will be delivered and be thoroughly dry when required. You should make arrangements for the supplying of the quantities of wood needed for next winter at each of the Indian schools in your agency. In this regard, please furnish an estimate of the quantities required, in order that you can receive the necessary authority to make the purchase.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 19-1-5 of the 1st instant, in regard to the report made to the Department by the Separate School Inspector on his recent inspection of the Suswah Indian Day School, and in reply I have the honour to report that with regard to water being in the cellar there may have been a very small amount soaked through the foundation during the time of the heavy flood in the spring but there was so very little that it could hardly be noticed and it all disappeared in a very short time. With regard to frost entering the cellar it is on account of the foundation not being banked with earth last fall. If it were banked around with earth I believe that it would prevent both water and frost entering. The cost of the work would be approximately $25.00.

In regard to a well being dug, I beg to report that on account of the building being on very high ground the cost of a well would be very high, but there is a spring within 500 feet of the school building where the teacher has been getting her supply for drinking and cooking which could be put in good condition at very little expense.

Arrangement has been made for a supply of wood for next winter's use, but it is not to be delivered at the school until it is needed as there is still about four double cords of wood in the yard at the school. On account of there being too much old wood left in the school yard last fall to deteriorate I thought it wise not to have any more put there until the old supply was burned. Some of the old wood has been lying around the yard for three years.

For next winter's use I consider that about fifteen cords of mixed wood, poplar and birch, will be sufficient for the school and residence.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, informing the Department regarding the condition of the cellar at the Buzah Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that only a very small quantity of water soaked through the foundation, due to the flood conditions in the spring. In order to prevent frost from entering the cellar, you may arrange later on in the season to have the foundation banked with earth. We note that the cost of having this done would be approximately $25. You should bear this matter in mind and have the necessary banking of the foundation attended to before the frost sets in next fall. Properly certified vouchers should be forwarded when the work has been completed, and you should refer to this letter as your authority for having the work done.

Owing to the cost, and also in view of the fact that water can be obtained from a spring, we are not prepared to authorize the digging of a well. You may, however, incur a small expenditure in having the spring which is located within 250 feet of the school building placed in good condition, in order that an adequate supply of water can be obtained for drinking and cooking purposes. This matter should be attended to during the coming summer. Properly certified vouchers should be rendered covering the expenditure incurred.

We note that you have arranged for the quantity of wood required for next winter's use, and that it will be delivered when the stock on hand has been used. We note that about 15 cords of mixed wood, poplar and birch, will be sufficient for the school and residence for next winter. You should arrange to have this wood delivered in due time to meet the requirements, and properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

Wall of classroom should be cleaned.
Floors should be oiled this summer.
Can a fence be put round property?

J. M. Bennett,
Inspector.
Ottawa, May 22, 1925.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Buzwah Indian Day School, recommends that the following repairs and improvements should be carried out:

1. Wall of classroom should be cleaned.
2. Floor should be oiled.
3. The school property should be fenced.
4. The school yard should be cleared of stumps and levelled.

Please report regarding the inspector's recommendations and state whether you would advise that any action be taken. If so, you should state the work that you would recommend be done and the approximate cost of the same. Your early reply is desired in order that, if it is decided to have any of the work done, it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
Sir:

In reply to Official Letter No.19-1-5 of the 22nd instant, relating to the Separate School Inspector's report on his recent inspection of the Buzwah School, I have the honour to report that the walls of the class-room should be renovated and the floor oiled; the total cost will not exceed twenty-five dollars.

With regard to fencing the property and cleaning the school yard, I would not recommend that this work be carried out at the present time, as the land where the school is situated has been only cleared of standing timber recently. The stumps have been cut low but are still quite green and it would be too costly a proposition to try to remove them at the present time. In a short period they will deteriorate and can be removed by a team and plow, then the yard can be cleaned, levelled and fenced at a reasonable cost.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Ottawa, June 4th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you recommend that the walls of the classroom in the Ruzwah Indian Day School be renovated and the floor oiled.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work done during the coming summer holidays. We note that you estimate the total cost will be approximately $25. When the work is completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

With reference to the fencing and cleaning of the school yard, the Department agrees with you that this work should stand over for the present.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I have the honour to enclose herewith a voucher in my favour amounting to $28.75 for payments made in connection with material purchased and labour performed at the Buswah Indian Day School.

The walls in the class-room and cloak rooms, and the walls and ceilings in the teacher's residence have been renovated with muresco, all the floors in the whole building have been scrubbed and oiled, the porch floors and steps have been painted, in fact the whole interior of the building has been cleaned and is now in good condition.

The yard around the school building grew up with weeds during the holidays which I authorized Peter Tehkumah to cut down and burn.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to report that a number of the teachers in the Indian Day Schools have been making enquiries as to the question of giving the pupils a few Christmas gifts at the end of the current quarter to encourage them in their school work.

In order to encourage the pupils I consider that a small donation should be made to each of the undermentioned schools for this purpose, as follows:

- Kaboni School: $6.00
- Buzwah: $6.00
- Sheguianadah: $5.00
- Whitefish Lake: $8.00

In presenting the Indian pupils with a few gifts at Christmas does not only encourage them at their studies, but it also pleases them and I believe encourages a better attendance.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Buzwah Indian Day School, states that the pump in the teacher's living quarters is in need of repair. He also states that the woodshed is entirely too small as it will not even hold enough dry kindling for the winter and he suggests that an addition be made in order to store the winter supply of fuel before the extreme cold weather sets in. He further states that he called the attention of the janitor and the teacher to the very unsanitary condition of the closets.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the pump repaired and placed in good order. You should, also, see that the closets are thoroughly cleaned out and placed in a sanitary condition. Relative to the enlarging of the woodshed, I shall be pleased if you will furnish a report on this matter stating the approximate cost of providing an addition which would be large enough to contain the supply of fuel used at this school. Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Buswah Indian Day School, states that the kitchen sink has no outlet and is very unsatisfactory. He states that if a pipe leading from the sink were installed this would solve the difficulty. Please arrange to have a proper outlet installed, in order that the sink can be placed in a serviceable condition.

The Inspector further recommends that a sanitary closet be supplied for the teacher. Please furnish your recommendation regarding this suggestion. If you recommend the installation of the closet, you should furnish particulars as to the type, cost, etc.

Please also report as to whether you would recommend the serving of a hot lunch to the pupils at midday, and, if so, state whether the teacher would prepare and serve same and if there are utensils on hand for the purpose. Full particulars as to the supplies, etc., required should be given.

Sir:—

In reply to Departmental Letter No. I9-I-5 of November 29th last, relative to the Separate School Inspector's report on the Buzwah School during his last visit, I have the honour to report that a drain pipe from the kitchen sink will be installed in the near future. It is quite difficult to have work of this kind done as there is not a plumber closer than Gore Bay which is a distance of 60 miles from the school.

With regard to the serving of a hot lunch to the pupils at midday, the teacher is willing to prepare and serve the same providing she is allowed an additional half hour at noon. As the parents of the pupils prepare very good lunches for the children to take with them to school I believe that a cup of hot cocoa for each pupil would be all that is necessary. In order to serve the cocoa only a few cups would be all that is necessary.

With regard to the installation of a sanitary closet, as there are two good warm toilets in connection with this building quite convenient, I would not recommend erecting a sanitary closet at present.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, December 10, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the recent report of the Separate School Inspector on his visit to the Buswah Indian Day School. It is noted that you will arrange to have the drain pipe from the kitchen sink installed at an early date.

Relative to the serving of a hot lunch to the pupils at midday, the Department agrees with you that it would be sufficient, in view of the fact that the parents prepare good lunches for the pupils to take with them to school, to augment this lunch by serving cocoa or tea. You may, therefore, arrange for the quantity of cocoa, tea and Drimilk powder, if the latter is required, and also for the purchase and delivery of the cups and any other utensils required in preparing and serving same. In the preparation and serving of this drink the teacher should obtain the help of the older girls. Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the supplies required for the serving of the hot drink.

Your remarks relative to the installation of a sanitary closet have been noted and no further action need be taken by you in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Manitowaning, October 16th, 1931.

Sir—

Referring to Departmental Letter No.19-1-5 of the 10th instant, with reference to the report of Miss Inga, Travelling Nurse, in which she recommends that soap and towels be supplied for the use of the pupils at the day schools in the Manitowaning Agency, I have the honour to report that all the day schools in this agency are supplied with wash basins, benches, soap and towels for the use of the pupils.

Since the receipt of the above letter I have been in touch with Wikwemikong, Kaboni, Buswah, Sheguinandah A.C., Sheguinandah R.C., and Birch Island Schools and found all these schools equipped with the above articles, with the exception of Birch Island school, as there are not any towels in use at present. There is a wash basin and a first class wash stand, but the teacher, Miss Lavallee, does not approve of towels for the pupils in the class room as she claims her policy is to teach the pupils to come from their homes to school in a clean condition, but I would recommend that a supply be furnished to this school as they are a necessity.

It might be well to furnish the Sheguinandah R.C. School with a few towels as the supply is almost exhausted.

When I visit Sucker Creek and Whitefish Lake reserves, making distribution of fall interest which should be in the near future, the two schools will be visited and a report made to the Department as to the above requirements.

The attendance has increased to such an extent that the seating capacity is crowded. At present, the number of seats in the classroom will accommodate twenty-three, and there are now twenty-nine on the roll. There are five rows of seats in the classroom so by installing five fronts and one back seat there would be sufficient accommodation for the number of pupils enrolled.

As a number of the pupils have a long distance to walk in the morning and evening, I believe that it would be advisable to serve hot cocoa with their midday meal in the classroom. The teacher is quite willing to prepare the hot drink if the Department will supply cocoa, milk and sugar.
Ottawa, October 31, 1931.

Sir:

Relative to that portion of your report on your inspection of the Buswah Indian Day School during the present month, regarding the need of further seating accommodation, I have to say that if you will inform the Department of the sizes and number of each size of front and rear seats required, consideration would be given to placing an order for same. For your information I may say that the desks at present in use in the school were obtained from the Globe Furniture Co., Ltd., Waterloo, Ont., in November, 1922. You shall obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose. As Miss King has twenty-seven on her roll and the school has only twenty-four seats, it would be well to provide her with, say, half a dozen additional desks.

Ottawa, November 6, 1931.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Buzwah Indian Day School in September, last, states that the teacher requires an alarm clock and thermometer. With regard to a hot lunch being served to the pupils in each school would say that hot cocoa should be served in each classroom during the cold weather. Sir:-

I have the honour to report that as the cool wet weather has now set in and a number of the Indian children who attend day schools have a long distance to walk to allow them to attend, and in many cases a cold dry lunch is all they have for their mid-day meal, it would be advisable for the Department to supply cocoa, sugar and milk, or such ingredients, that would allow the teachers to prepare a hot drink to serve with the mid-day lunch. This would be healthful to the pupils and would encourage a better attendance during the winter months.

I would recommend that the Department approve of the serving of a hot drink from December 1st, to March 31st, 1935, at the schools mentioned below and for the following amounts:

Manitowaning, November 12th, 1936.

Sir:—

I have the honour to report that as the cold wet season will soon set in and the majority of the Indian pupils who attend day schools have long distances to walk to enable them to attend, and in many cases a cold dry lunch is all they have for nourishment at mid-day. It would be well for the Department to again supply cocoa, sugar and milk, or such ingredients, as has been done in past winters, to enable the teachers to prepare a hot drink to serve with the mid-day lunch to pupils in attendance from a distance from the schools. This, during the past winters, has been healthful to the children and did encourage better attendance.

I would recommend that the Department approve of the following amounts being allowed to the day schools of this agency, from December 1st 1936 to March the 31st 1937, monthly:

| School                  | Amount |
|-------------------------|--------|
| Buzwah                  | $4     |
| Kaboni                  | 4      |
| Sheguian dah C.E.       | 3      |
| Sheguian dah R.C.       | 3      |
| Sucker Creek            | 3      |
| Whitefish Lake          | 4      |
| Wikwemikong senior and junior classrooms | 10 |

The amount of $6 a month was allowed the Wikwemikong school during the last winter past. As there are two classrooms in this school and a large attendance of children the amount of $6 is not sufficient to provide a hot drink to all the pupils so I would recommend that the allowance be increased to $10.00 monthly.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Indian Agent,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant no provision has been made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for the funds that would be required to give a general cleaning to all the day schools in your Agency.

The plan which you wish to adopt is a good one but, as mentioned above, funds at our disposal will not permit favourable consideration being given to it. You might bring the matter up again when times become normal.

In the meantime the teachers should be urged to encourage the senior pupils to take an interest in the cleanliness of the schools. If they do this it is felt that considerable cleaning that might otherwise be necessary could be avoided with consequent saving of expenditure.

Yours truly,

H.A. Hosy,

Sir:-

The walls have formerly had muresco applied, which is very difficult to remove to prepare for painting, but once the walls are painted they can be easily washed.

As the walls in the living quarters are somewhat checked it was thought advisable to apply wall paper, and the teacher, Miss Wakegijig, has offered to apply the paper, if material is supplied.
