Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

You will find enclosed herewith a requisition for requisition for a few articles required for Buswah School.

There is no clock, and Mrs. Trudeau would prefer to have an alarm clock. A new lock is required on the outside entrance to kitchen, which is situated on north side of building, and should also be fitted with storm door. A combination door would be most satisfactory as it will also serve as a screen door in summer. The kitchen stove is in very poor condition, and is fit only for an Indian camp stove. The fire back is burnt out, which could probably be replaced, but there is also a break through to the oven, which allows ashes to sift through and makes it very difficult to bake.

The stove quoted on is exactly the same as the one supplied for Birch Island School last year, a Findlay Oval Range with copper reservoir, but no warming closet. These are an excellent stove, and the local hardware dealer has one in stock at the present time. A few pipes and elbows are also required.

As these items are all very urgently required, I would recommend their purchase locally at an early date. A small additional cost will be required to set up the stove, fit the storm door and lock.

C. R. Johnston,
Indian Agent
Ottawa,
October 22, 1943.

Mr. C.R. Johnston, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, I am requesting the Purchasing Branch to secure the stove for the Buzwah teacher's residence. When you are advised that this stove is purchased, you may secure the pipes and elbows required. The Department also approves the purchase, for use at this school, of one alarm clock, one lock for kitchen door and one combination storm door. The cost of these should not exceed the price quoted in your letter.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

I wish to report the following repairs are required at Buzwah School. There is about 65 feet of eave troughing rusted out and needs replacing at an estimated cost of $15.00 for labour and material.

A small platform at residence entrance needs replacing, requiring about 100 board feet of lumber, and a few spikes and nails. About $8.00 should cover cost of material and labour, making a total estimated expenditure of $26.00.

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for Buzwah Indian Day School.

The prices are quoted from C. W. Hinds and S. W. McPhee & Co., Manitowaning, and T. Eaton Co. Toronto catalogue.

I wish to report a new toilet is required at Buzweh School, one of the old ones having blown down, and wrecked in a wind storm this fall.

L. A. Buck, Lumber Dealer and Contractor of Little Current, has quoted a price of $91.35 to furnish material and construct a toilet 5' X 6' X 7' with two panes of glass, ventilator and box, made of white pine cove siding, T & G. flooring, shiplap roof with cedar shingles, all corners and eaves trimmed.

The above price is F. O. B. truck, Little Current, and will cost approximately $15.00 for trucking and setting up at the school.

I believe this to be cheaper than purchasing material, and having it built at the school, and would recommend the offer be accepted.

Memorandum:

Inspection of Buzwah Indian Day School.

TEACHER -

The teacher is Mrs. L.J. Peltier who holds a Quebec Elementary Certificate. She has had nine years experience in Indian schools and two years in Provincial schools. Her discipline is fairly good and her children tested fairly well. Three entrance pupils went from this school last year to Spanish. The work is presented to them in an interesting manner. The assignments are given in a rather slip shod way. Their knowledge of English is fair. It would probably benefit the Grade Seven pupils if they were sent to Spanish next year.

This teacher needs to attend Summer School and to improve her teaching methods. In Grade 1 reading there is too much word calling at the present time. When they speed up in their reading, the result is a sing song rhythm with no expression. I advised the teacher that she must place more emphasis on oral English. At the present time, she seems to be depending upon reading to give oral English practice.

BUILDING AND TEACHERAGE -

This is an older type of school with fair lighting. There are five windows on one side with none on the other. The windows are too high and the room is not too bright. The room is fairly clean and the space is adequate. It is heated from a box stove with a pipe across the room. The building was erected in 1922. The teacher's quarters consist of the usual living room, kitchen and two bedrooms. Mrs. Peltier lives there with her husband who is a general timber contractor. She is attempting to plan to
attend the University of Ottawa Summer School next year.

RECOMMENDATIONS -

(1) This building is badly in need of a new roof. Arrangements should be made to order shingles. I understand that Mr. Peltier will submit a tender to replace the present roof.

(2) A new stove should be provided.

(3) A new fence is required but I think a hedge would suffice.

BFN/HM.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario:

Re: Inspection Report
Manitoulin Island Schools

During my recent visit to Manitoulin Island Agency I was able to visit the following schools and make the following notes concerning them.

BUZWAH
The building is in fair condition outside, a few general repairs being needed. The classroom requires painting and should be done during the summer. The pump in the residence is broken and should be repaired or replaced and a hot water reservoir is needed for the kitchen stove. The stove is a Findlay Oval 99-18X.

The class was in session and appeared to be orderly and interested. It being near the end of the school year possibly helped in this respect.

KABONI
This School was closed, the teacher having taken the pupils on a picnic. Apparently, they had kept school open June 6th to make up for this. Possibly a good idea but one that should have been sanctioned by the local Superintendent.

A walk consisting of large flat stones had been laid from the gate to the entrance. It was very rough and I would consider it dangerous. It would be preferrable to raise the walk out of the surrounding clay with either crushed stone or cement.

A number of minor repairs and painting is required. This will be covered by Mr. Johnston.

MURRAY HILL
This new school is well built and the class was in session during my visit. The room was filled to capacity and everyone seemed to take pride in the new building.
There are several odd jobs to be done yet. The installation of the furnace pipes is not complete. Several jobs around the windows, which also have to be painted.

The temporary building used as a warehouse when building was in progress is something of an eye sore. I would recommend that it be sold to some Indian for removal. There is adequate storage in the school basement.

A well to provide drinking water is needed in this locality.

**WICKWIMEKONG-Jr. Room**

This building needs a considerable number of minor repairs. Ceilings in the classroom and residence need to be patched. The classroom floor is warped and should be levelled.

Screens are needed for some of the classroom windows. These could be made up if screen moulding and wire were supplied.

The Delco plant is at the factory being repaired. This could be traced to ensure its return before school opens again.

An outside door at the entrance to the residence is in very poor shape and should be replaced. The size is 2'6" x 6'6" with hardware. Some painting needs to be done and some other small items all of which should be covered by Mr. Johnston.

**WICKWIMEKONG-Sr. Room**

Painting inside is the main requirement here. The teacher complained about not having enough blackboard space. At present there is 18 feet. An extra set of blackboards is available at Murray Hill school. These were duplicated and could be transferred.

**SHEGUINDAH**

This old school is reported to me as having been closed for about 12 years. The Band desire to take it over and repair it for use as a Council Hall. Mr. Johnston is of the opinion that it was built from Band Funds. You might ascertain if this is so and possibly release it to the Band. There does not appear to be much hope of it being used as a school.

**SUCKER CREEK**

This building needs to be painted, also required is a new outside door. Mr. Johnston advised me he had authority to get this door. Any other minor repairs should be included in Mr. Johnston's report.

**WEST BAY VILLAGE SCHOOL**

There are 52 pupils in this two room school. It was closed and one of the teachers had left before I arrived. The ceiling of the Junior room should be painted white. At present it looks nice.
It is very dark with no light reflection. Patches of plaster and the floor in the Senior room need attention.

A new pump is on hand and should be installed. The old one is not working at all. One electric light outlet in the store-room is not working.

For use during the hot weather, I would recommend that a two burner electric grill be supplied. It would be cheaper to use than wood in the cookstove and much more comfortable for the teachers.

LAKEVIEW

WEST BAY - NEW SCHOOL

I could not get inside this building. It is the best looking Day School I have seen anywhere. It could have been raised up a little higher whilst being built as there was a little water around.

BIRCH ISLAND

Judged from the outside, this school appeared to be in pretty good condition. According to Mr. Johnston and Chief McGregor, it was very much overcrowded and another room is required. It would be possible to extend the building by the addition of another room without spoiling the appearance and I would recommend that this be given consideration when the next estimates are being prepared.

The above report covers only the most important points in connection with the schools. Paint appears to be the greatest need in most cases. It is expected that Mr. Johnston will be forwarding the necessary requisitions etc. to have as much work as possible done during the holidays.

F. Matters,

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Cape Croker April 2nd 1896.

Sir,

Enclosed please find the school teachers quarterly returns for the three schools on this Reserve for 3rd March quarter last. Also requisitions for their salaries for above named quarter.

There has been a severe cold or some sort of epidemic going round amongst the people in that part of the country and Mr. Wangh was laid up for a week with it. He could not leave his barber house, he was so ill with it. Consequently his school was closed for that week. Miss Miller went to Hobarton on business and the roads became snow blocked so that she could not get back for a few days. I made no deductions from their salaries on account of this lost time. I understand teachers are allowed a certain number of days on account of sickness and other unavoidable lost days. Taking the hard winter into consideration our schools have been kept open pretty well and I believe the teachers tried to do their duty faithfully and well. I have to inform you that several cases of the measles have broken out on the reserve and the Capoocan school has been closed yesterday. Should any case appear at Sirisay or Port Elgin I think it would be well to close them as well for a time. This disease has been in the White settlement adjoining and Winston it appears like a very violent form of measles in some cases called German measles. The doctor informs me that it is harder on the dark skinned race and so many of the Indians having weak lungs there is almost sure to be fatalities. We will however do our best to get them proper attention. It will be impossible to stop from going through as the farming township is full of it. I am glad that the weather has commenced to be colder and the season is in our favor.

I have the honor to remain your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to report that on account of the sickness all the schools have been closed.

The doctor is faithfully in his charge. Yesterday he called on fifteen cases and was still midnight preparing medicines. His help will average more than an attendance on even other day visits. His prayers and help coming all the way from here.

The sicknesses are going hard with the adults but through the care of the Dr. and white friends only one death has occurred as yet.

In many cases whole families are down, some numbering as many as eight or ten in the family.

This is the best doctor who has attended these Indians. He is working all his efforts.

29 Jan 1905

Secretary General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa:

Dear Sir:

On this reserve of Cape Croker, the Indians are divided between two different religions. A little more than half of them are Methodists, and the rest are Catholics.

There are three schools, and these are public schools, or more correctly, they are in fact Protestant schools, as they are taught by Protestant teachers.

The Indian Act directs that in each Reserve there must be one teacher of the denomination to which belongs the majority; although the minority may have also their own school if they have a sufficient number of children. Consequently, the Catholics of this place have the right to have a separate school. However, as they wish to give no unnecessary cause of discontent (even unreasonable) to their brethren of the Methodist denomination who live in the vicinity of the school building now in use near the Catholic church, they wish, for the present time, be satisfied that it remains a public school, where no religion shall be taught in the class-room during the regular hours; but they want to have a Catholic teacher recommended by their residing priest, in order that before and after hours, and on Saturdays and Sundays, religious teaching and education may be given to their children.
According to the spirit of their faith.

And now, dear sir, not to praise myself, but to encourage you to listen to my request, I beg to call your attention to the fact that same the same Father Oshie who may have been a little troublesome to your Department in the past, but always with the only intention of obtaining for our Indians what proved to be very advantageous to them. It may be remembered that ten years ago I found at Garden River a miserable school with an altogether insufficient teacher and an average of 15 or 16 children, and when I left four years later we had there a nice school building, two teachers, and the average was running between 50 and 55. Later on, having been in charge of the missions of the Manitoulin island, I found the day schools in the worst condition, and after a while, to use the expression of Mr. Inspector White, I found the solution of the Indian schools' problem, in engaging as teachers ladies of a certain society who have brought an extraordinary change for the better in the five reserves where I placed them. Now, I have been sent here to establish a new center of Catholic missions, and wish to do the same good as elsewhere. I dare say that I am sure of the result if you grant me what I ask today for the Catholic Indians of Cape Croker, namely: that the school (of one of those in operation)
now taught by a Protestant lady near the Catholic Church, and in the portion of the reserve where Catholics are in majority, should be given to my care. It will remain, as I said already, a public school, but I would have to teach a Catholic lady as those that give so great satisfaction in the Manitoulin island. She will come with an assistant and keep as boarders the few Catholic children that live too far to come as day scholars. The school building is large enough for that; only two or three partitions ought to be made to separate rooms, and the necessary articles of furniture ought to be purchased for the teacher.

This plan has been exposed to the Chief and some of the principal men of the Catholic congregation, and they all are very desirous to see it accepted and realised as soon as possible.

When you answer me favorably, I will take measures to have an excellent teacher ready for after the summer holidays.

I remain, dear sir,

Your servant in the Lord.

OTTAWA, 10th February, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

Mr McIver, Agent for the Cape Croker reserve, forwards two communications from Rev. Father Artus, Roman Catholic missionary at that place with reference to the existing schools on the reserve, claiming that as there are a number of Roman Catholic children they are entitled to a school of their own faith. He says, however, in order not to cause unnecessary discontent to their Methodist brethren, they would be satisfied with an undenominational school where no religion would be taught in the class-room during school hours, upon condition that the teacher of the school be a Roman Catholic who should have the privilege of giving religious instruction before and after hours and on Saturdays and Sundays to the Roman Catholic children attending the school.

There are three day schools on this reserve, Cape Croker, Sidney Bay and Port Elgin, which are, or should all be undenominational. The whole expense of these schools is borne by the Band, who have passed rules and regulations for their management under Section 76 of the Indian Act, which were confirmed by His Excellency, the Governor General in Council on the 11th April, 1891. See file 114636.

The Cape Croker Band numbers 369, of whom 124 are Roman Catholics, 230 Methodists and 15 Anglicans. The children of school age number 59, about
20 of whom would be Roman Catholics.

I find that 11 boys and 2 girls from this reserve are at the Roman Catholic Industrial school at Wikwemikong, which would leave a small number of children of that faith on the reserve.

Up to the present time the Roman Catholics on the reserve have made no complaint and I do not see that there is any necessity for establishing a purely Roman Catholic school there. They have a resident missionary who would be free to give religious instruction to children of his faith, but as the Roman Catholic Church adjoins the Cape Croker school, as you will see from the accompanying photograph, I do not why it should not be used for religious exercises and training of the children. The fact that the present teacher is a Methodist is purely accidental, as when she was appointed no mention was made or question asked in regard to her religious belief. I think that if the Agent is instructed to give orders that no religious teaching shall be given during school hours, Father Artus would have no ground of complaint, especially as he is not opposed to an undenominational school.

In any event the request for a separate Roman Catholic school would have to come from the Indians as they would have to bear the expense.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Since the date of my memorandum of the 10th February last on the subject of the claim made by Rev. Father Artus, Roman Catholic missionary on the Cape Croker reserve, for a school for the Indians of his church Father Artus has been urging his point with the Department and the Indians. His first proposition was that one of the schools on the reserve (the one at Cape Croker preferably) should be placed in charge of a Roman Catholic teacher to be conducted as an undenominational school. His second recommendation is that he be allowed to appoint two Sisters to take charge of this school and he attended a meeting of the council lately held by the Cape Croker Band and addressed the Indians in favor of his latter suggestion.

Mr Agent McIver forwards a Resolution of the Council postponing the consideration of the question until the next meeting.

As I pointed out in my previous memorandum the Cape Croker Band pays for the maintenance of their schools and have passed regulations under the Act for their management. The schools are all undenominational and the Department has lately given orders that no religious instruction shall be imparted during...
school hours at any of the schools attended by Roman Catholic children.

I can see no objection to the employment of a Roman Catholic teacher at one of the Cape Croker schools if possessed of the necessary qualifications and the fact that one is not so employed is simply because none have ever applied.

The Regulations above referred to passed by the Band do not provide for the appointment of teachers of any denomination, and unless the Band in Council passes a Resolution favoring the establishment of a denominational school, the Department would not be called upon to interfere.

With regard to Father Artus' second recommendation as to the employment of two Sisters to take charge of the school, I do not think that this should be entertained as Father Artus wishes to have them on the reserve for the purpose of starting a boarding school. These Sisters, though a teaching order, are not possessed of the necessary Provincial certificates. They do very well for outlying reserves where it is difficult to get qualified teachers, but in case it is decided to employ a Roman Catholic teacher, either of the Separate School Inspectors would be in a position to recommend a suitable person for the position.

I would call your attention to the concluding paragraph of Agent McIver's letter of the 1st instant in which states that Father Artus seems to think that he as Agent, and all the Indians belonging to his Church should just obey his commands and that he is very severe on some of his own people.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the two letters hereunder from Father Artus, Roman Catholic missionary at Cape Croker, apparently addressed to Rt. Rev. Thomas J. Dowling, B.C., Bishop of Hamilton, and the petition from the Roman Catholic portion of the Nawash Band asking that one of the three teachers employed on the Cape Croker reserve be of that persuasion and that Rev. Father Artus have the selection of such teacher, I beg to say that this matter has been before the Department since February last and has received the consideration of the Cape Croker Band in Council, who asked that the discussion of this question be postponed until the next Council meeting. The Department, in replying to Mr. Agent McIver's letter enclosing this resolution, informed him that it would await the result of the deliberations of the Band, but that it was not inclined to favor the appointment of Sisters as suggested, as it preferred to have regularly qualified teachers. This was on the 17th June last and since that date no further communication on this subject has been received from our Agent.

In my previous memoranda of the 10th Feb. and 10th June last, I pointed out that any change in the personnel of the school would have to be
initiated by the Band in Council, as they pay for the maintenance of their schools and have passed regulations under the Act for their management.

The schools are all non-denominational and the Department has lately given orders that no religious instruction shall be imparted during school hours at any of the schools attended by Roman Catholic children.

I see can see no objection to the employment of a Roman Catholic teacher at one of the Cape Croker schools if possessed of the necessary qualifications and the fact that one is not so employed is due to the fact that none have ever applied.

Father Artus over-estimates the percentage of Roman Catholics in the Band when he places them at two-fifths; they number about one-third and could not have 27 children of school age, as claimed by him, especially as there are about 13 Roman Catholic children attending the Industrial school at Wikwemikong.

The Roman Catholic Indians are scattered over the Reserve like the others, and it would be impossible for all their children to attend one school as day pupils, but to overcome this difficulty Father Artus states that the Sisters placed in charge of one of the schools would take the children who live too far away as boarders, thus inserting the thin edge of the wedge for the establishment of a boarding school which is not needed on the reserve.

Notwithstanding Father Artus' desire for a speedy decision, the matter should remain in abeyance until the decision of the Cape Croker Council.
is reached, and even if it is in accordance with Father Artus' wishes it is doubtful whether the Department would be justified in acceding to all his demands. The appointment of a Roman Catholic teacher, as I have before stated, might be conceded if asked for, but he should not have the appointment. Even on Manitoulin Island, to which he refers, the Roman Catholic missionary has only the nomination of teachers.

In my previous memoranda I pointed out that the spiritual welfare of the Indians of this Band can be well looked after by the missionaries who are resident on the reserve and have churches conveniently situated.

Martin Benson

Dear Sir,

Mr. Agent Mr. Iver of Cape Croker communicated to me this morning your letter No. 152521 of the 7th inst., in reference to the Catholic teacher to be appointed for the school No. 1 of this reserve. He, not less than I, is surprised to see the manner how the matter is understood, viz.: altogether differently from what was intended and asked for.

I had the honour to write to you myself some time last spring. Later on I presented again the request of the Catholics to Mr. Mr. Iver, who, as I think, sent it to you. Then in the town-hall of the band, in presence of the Agent, and the Indians being assembled in council, I expressed in English and in French what we were wishing for. Besides this lordship, the Bishop of Hamilton has sent one of his priests to Ottawa, to recommend this affair to the Department. In each of these many occasions, what was asked is:

1) That the teacher in one (No. 1) of the three schools of this reserve should be always a Catholic One .... and ...

2) As I understand that some Protestant children having to come to that school, no Religion should be taught at-class hours, we insisted upon obtaining also that the said teacher should be...
detected by the missionary among the members of that association of teaching ladies that I have already placed in the catholic schools of the Manitoulin island. Any other teacher, said I, even a catholic one, could not give satisfaction as we could not expect him to teach before and after class, and on Saturdays and Sundays, without an extra salary. I added also that my intention is that the teacher being assisted by one or two friends, should take care to be among the children living far away, ...with no expenses to the band or to the Department. Now it is evident that an ordinary teacher could not do it.

All this has been proposed to your Department by myself and by the Bishop's Delegate. I said it clearly to the Indians in council, and they gave a vote favorable to it. I consequently hope that we will be allowed taking charge of that school, on the aforesaid conditions and under the responsibility of the Missionary.

I am not unknown to the Department of Indian Affairs. I may have given occasion to some trouble to its officers, but I believe they must recognize that I always had in view the best interests of the Indians and that so far I have been successful. — Coming to Garden River ten years ago I found a miserable school with
an average of nearly 20 irregular pupils; and after 4 years I left in the place a large school with two teachers and an average between 45 and 50. Then I have been in charge four years of the missions in the Manitoulin island. No? While, now principal of the normal school, was then inspector and he used to complain with me of the unfitness of all the day schools. Then, after much difficulty I introduced the ladies of the society already mentioned, and the same Mr. Inspector. While I am often visiting again, "Father, you have found the solution of the Indian schools' problem. Place these excellent teachers everywhere." So I did, and the change for the better is incredible not only in the schools, but even in the families of the pupils. — How I have been appointed in a new field, with residence at Cape Croker, with the expectation that my efforts must be blessed here as elsewhere.

At the Cape Indians have money enough to pay qualified teachers, and they have them (3 of them) since many years. And however (they say it themselves) they know nothing, they have very little education, the school is a failure, as it was formerly in the Manitoulin. — Let me have the teacher I want with her assistant so that will cost nothing to the band, and in a little while you will be surprised of the improvement. I have secured for the Cape a first class teacher.
with years of experience and the best of recommendations which is better than certificates. She will be ready to start teaching on the 1st of January.

One more day, apologizing for this long letter; this is what has been asked of the Indians in council and accepted by them.

Please dear Sir, for the sake of the true civilization of the Indians, answer favorable as soon as possible.

Remain dear Sir,

Your servant in the Lord,

J. A. Curtis

OTTAWA, 23rd October, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General

With reference to the contemplated placing of No.1 school on the Cape Croker reserve in charge of a Roman Catholic teacher after 1st January next, I beg to say that a communication has been received from Rev. Father Artus, Roman Catholic missionary on this reserve in which he presses his claim for the nomination and appointment of a teacher. A letter has also been received from Mr Agent McIver practically approving of Father Artus' proposals.

The proposition of Father Artus is, that he be allowed to place a nun belonging to an American teaching order in charge of this school, who will have a companion to take up residence with her on the reserve, and take eight or ten Indians children as boarders. This is practically the establishment of a boarding school on the reserve in charge of the Sisters. Father Artus claims that the Department will not be called upon to pay anything for the maintenance of the Sisters or the children taken in beyond the payment of the teacher's salary. This arrangement might last for a short time, but we know that it would not be long before the Department would be called upon to recognize it as a boarding school.

The original claim of Father Artus was
that as there were a number of Roman Catholic Indians on the Cape Croker reserve, they were entitled to have a teacher of their faith in one of the three schools. The Department agreed that if the Indians were desirous of having such a teacher it would meet their wishes by appointing a Roman Catholic teacher with the Ontario provincial qualifications on the understanding that no religious instruction be given during school hours, as Protestants and well as Catholics would have to attend the school. Father Artus is not satisfied with this arrangement and calls attention to the good work done by some of the Sisters on the North Shore and Manitoulin Island. The conditions are entirely different on the Cape Croker reserve.

In the section referred to by Father Artus, all the Indians are Roman Catholics, and it was next to impossible to get a white teacher to take charge of the schools there. The Indians in Cape Croker are more advanced and white teachers can readily be found who are willing to live amongst them. The Roman Catholics at Cape Croker are in the minority.

I think that, instead of trying the experiment proposed by Father Artus and letting it have a fair trial, as suggested by the Agent, it would be well to let the arrangement made by the Department be tried first, although I feel sure under the existing circumstances, that it would never satisfy Father Artus, who will never rest content until he attains his end. It is for the Department to decide whether it will give away to Father Artus now or advise the Agent to carry out its previous instructions regarding the appointment of a teacher.
Even with a Roman Catholic lay teacher the school may be considered undenominational, but it would be difficult to imagine a school taught by a nun as meeting this requirement. There is no doubt about the success of the Sisters in their work but their efforts should be confined to Bands who are all Roman Catholics.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent McIver forwards a letter from Rev. Father Artus in further reference to the proposed placing of Cape Croker No.1 school under a Roman Catholic teacher.

Some months ago Father Artus recommended the appointment of a Miss Moffatt, who is a member of a teaching order of Sisters in the United States. He was told that if she possessed the required qualifications and was a British Subject, the Department would approve of her temporary appointment. As she could not fill the Department's requirements, the services of the present teacher were retained until the close of the current fiscal year.

Father Artus wishes to be in a position to take over the school after the summer holidays and is willing to expend money in making repairs to the building, provided that he be given the right to "select the teacher from among the over-said Society of teaching ladies, whether they are British subjects or not, or whether they have or not Canadian certificates". He asks the right to select a teacher upon his own responsibility and he says that if the Department insists upon the Roman Catholic teacher being a British subject with a Canadian certificate, he will recommend Miss Moffatt, who is prepared to become a Canadian citizen and obtain the required certificate.
If, however, he is not given a free choice and any restrictions are placed on him, he will not contribute anything towards the necessary repairs to the building.

As the building is the property of the Band I do not see that Father Artus is called upon to spend any of his money upon it, as they can well afford to make any necessary repairs.

He claims that he had a free hand when he was at Wikwemikong in selecting teachers, and perhaps he had, but the question of nationality had never arisen in that connection, nor were the other conditions similar. The Indians of Cape Croker are more advanced in civilization and there is a better prospect of obtaining qualified white teachers there than there was on Manitoulin Island and the North Shore.

The whole question amounts to this—that Father Artus wishes to control the situation and Agent McIver says that the Roman Catholic Indians and Father Artus will not rest until the proposed scheme is tried. I see no reason from receding from the stand already taken by the Department.

In fact it is so difficult to find such persons that for several years even the priests could not but very seldom meet with any. Only five years ago, while I was in charge, I found a society of teaching ladies that accepted very generously to come to our missions. They did so, and there is only one opinion of all about them. They succeed better than was ever expected. Now of these ladies some are British subjects; some are not; some have Canadian certificates; some have none, and in selecting the ones who should come and teach our schools I would like to be able to pick up always the very best in all respects, those who could teach the children both music and different kinds of housework, knitting, sewing etc., even if they happen to have no Canadian Certificate. The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to Rev. Mr Nelson's concluding remarks in his letter to Dr Sutherland regarding Indian matters on Cape Croker reserve, and especially relating to schools there, I beg to say Mr Nelson is not quite seized of the facts regarding the appointment of a Roman Catholic teacher at Cape Croker. Now Father Artus, who was missionary there, claimed that as there were 131 Roman Catholics in that Band, out of a total population of 386; 240 of whom are Methodists and the remaining 15 Anglicans, the Roman Catholics were entitled to have a teacher of their own faith in one of the three schools on the reserve.

After considerable correspondence, the Department decided that his contention was just and agreed to the appointment of a teacher who was a Roman Catholic. The school, however, was to be conducted as an undenominational school with no religious instruction during school hours.

The teacher recommended by Father Artus was employed and Mr Inspector Clendinning in his report on this school made in November last, says that he thinks "she will do well and be valuable among the Indians. Teaching first class".

With regard to the closing of the Port Elgin and Sidney Bay schools, this was done at the recommendation of the Agent, who reported that owing to
their being no accommodation near the wheel for the teachers, and the unsatisfactory attendance during the winter months, it was a matter of economy to close the schools. The teacher at Port Elgin had resigned, but at the request of the Indians, who forwarded a resolution asking to put this school in charge of an Indian named Thomas Jones, he was allowed to continue it during the winter months and is still in charge. After the 30th instant he will have to qualify if he wishes to be retained.

No similar request was made for the appointment of a substitute for the Sidney Bay school and it was closed from the 1st Jan. to the 31st March.

The Indians of Cape Croker pay for their schools out of their own funds. These schools are all denominational and have always been supported by the Band.

Cape Croker, Ont., 1st March 19

To the Chief and the Councillors of Cape Croker Band.

We, the Catholics of Cape Croker, respectfully ask the Chief and the Councillors to allow the Teacher of the School No. 1 to teach our children their prayers and their catechism during class, five minutes every day. During that time the other children will be given something else to do, in order not to loose their time. Or else, if you prefer, they could have a little recess outside.

The reason why we
ask this is that our priest cannot attend to their religious instruc-
tion regularly, being often absent or being often too busy while at home.

You are aware that, being the minority here, we are enti-
tled to a separate school (Indian act chap. 43 sect. 76.)

But we do not ask for a separate school, because the Band would have to build another School House. That is why to avoid any further cost we would be satisfied with what we are asking now.

Hoping you will be kind enough to grant a so fair and just request,

We remain,
very respectfully yours,

The Catholics of Cape Croker.

Sir:

Resolution No. 4 refers to a supply of water for the school. The question of a well was also discussed. The Indians wanted a well for each school, which would be very expensive and the pumps very often get out of repair.

I advised dealing with one school at a time, and pointed out the great privilege there was for water works from their good spring at the foot of the hill, telling them it was just a question of laying pipe and two inches would be sufficient with an inch pipe leading into each house, school, church, and watering troughs for stock. There is a good fall all the way down from the spring. It can be done for less money than it will take to dig wells. All the people on both sides of that street could pay equal share as well as the school and church, and I wanted to leave them something & remember me by as I expect to leave them shortly.

Mr. Duff, the Markdale District representative in the Department of Agriculture, gave the Owen Sound Sun some interesting facts of the work on the Cape Croker Reservation. In its interview with him the paper said:

"The last fair in this Northern section of Mr. Duff's district was held on Tuesday on the Cape Croker Indian reserve on the Georgian Bay. Mr. Duff was greatly pleased with what he saw up there and the interest taken in the fair by the Indians. "The progress of the Indians was a surprise," he said, "and I would never have believed there are such splendid specimens of manhood amongst the fine big, strapping fellows. Intelligent and many of them well educated. They took up the school fair idea enthusiastically and we had a splendid fair. The president, secretary and director were all Indians and at the little concert they had on fair night, the president took the chair and presided over the meeting as well as anyone could do. Some of them are excellent speakers, especially one of them, Paul Jones, who made a splendid speech. Then they sing and play different instruments most willingly was heard.

Mr. Duff paid tribute to the school teacher there, a white woman. "She is a wonder," said he. "She teaches the school, trains the children from which the members of the 125th Regiment Indian Band are selected, teaches them singing and music, domestic science, sewing and manual training. She spends her summer months taking a course at Guelph, in order to fit her better for her work. As the priest, Father Caroli, says, "She knows everything she does and was doing new to me," concluded Mr. Duff, "and if you want some good news for your paper, you had better come with me to the next school fair. You will see plenty to write about, for it is an interesting place and is well worth a trip there to see it."

The Penny Bank

A philanthropic institution for the development of thrift among Canadian school children, depending on the united voluntary services of school teachers and of the chartered banks.
The Working of the System.

1. The Class-room.

On Monday morning in each class, during a period when the children are at work from the blackboard, those who wish to make deposits are called up in the order of their names in the Cash Book. One at a time, each child presents his Pass Book and his money—the latter going into a special tray. After the child has seen the teacher enter the amount of his deposit opposite his name in the Cash Book as well as in his Pass Book and date and initial the latter, he passes on to his desk and to his work.

When the last child has sat down again the teacher counts the cash and puts it in her class money bag, entering the amount upon the tag and sending bag and Cash Book to the Principal's office.

NEW DEPOSITS.

When a child makes his first deposit, the teacher sends to the Principal for an index card and a Pass Book bearing the same number. It is essential that the index card which identifies the child should be numbered to agree with his own Pass Book.

NOTICE OF WITHDRAWAL.

Notice must be given by any depositor wishing to withdraw more than a dollar. The proper form will be supplied and initialled by the teacher.

LOST PASS BOOKS.

Lost Pass Books must be reported at once to the teacher who will fill out the proper form and give the counterfoil to the child. Index cards for new accounts, withdrawal notices and lost pass book forms should all go with the Cash Book and money bag to the Principal's office.

On the last banking day of each month every child should produce his Pass Book so that the teacher may enter the balance in the Cash Book under the heading "Balance as it appears in Pass Book." Teachers should also make and enter in the Cash Book the cross additions of the individual deposits shewn therein and see that the total for the month agrees with the sum of the weekly totals, in order to discover errors which might otherwise get into the Ledger.

The Principal's Office.

Before the first banking Monday of a school term, the Principal may select two boys or two girls, who volunteer to act, and who in his judgment can afford to give up a lesson period each Monday for the sake of acquiring skill in handling cash and obtaining a little practice in business methods. These two pupils, under the Principal's supervision, can do the following work:

After all the returns from the various class-rooms have reached the Principal's office, count the cash in each bag and verify the total as entered upon the tag and in the corresponding Cash Book—any error being reported to the teacher concerned before the classes have dispersed. Prepare the Principal's Summary in duplicate. Place the index cards, the withdrawal notices, the lost pass book forms, and the transfer forms (see below) in an envelope with one copy of the Principal's Summary. This package goes with the money to the Bank.

TRANSFERS.

A child who has come from another school in the same town and who had a banking account in that other school should make application to his new Principal for a transfer form and should give up his old Pass Book. The Principal will make out a new index card, give the child the corresponding new Pass Book into which he has transferred the old balance and attach both the old Pass Book and the new index card to the transfer form.

OLD PASS BOOKS AND INDEX CARDS.

When these are returned by the Bank, it means that the child has drawn out all his money and that the account is closed. The old Pass Books should be kept in numerical order and the old index cards in alphabetical order for use in the event of the child wishing to re-open his account. They may be destroyed one year after the child has left school.

INTEREST.

The children should be told that interest will be added only to those accounts which show any balance on the 30th June. Sometimes children lose interest which might have been secured by leaving five cents to keep the account open.

On the last banking day of each month the Cash Books, instead of being returned to the teachers, are sent to the Bank in order that the total monthly deposits of each child may be posted to his account in the Ledger, and that account compared with the Pass Book Balance as it is shown in the Cash Book.
3. The Bank.

When the Bank receives a new index card, the particulars thereon are entered upon a new page in the school Ledger, which page must bear the same number as that upon the card, while the card itself is placed in the cabinet at the Bank as an index to the Ledger.

The withdrawal notices for the week should be upon the paying teller's desk before the hour set apart for withdrawals. Notices not acted upon within a month of their issue will be destroyed. These notices are not cheques and must never be treated as such. Withdrawals take place once a week during a stated hour. The Pass Book must be presented and compared with the Ledger. In doubtful cases the child should know the date of his birth as given on his page in the Ledger. The debit entry must be made at once on both the Pass Book and Ledger and the child must sign the withdrawal sheet. If the child draws out all his money, the Pass Book is retained by the Bank while the corresponding index card is removed from the cabinet and both returned to the school that issued them.

When the Bank has received a lost pass book form a dated entry consisting of the words "Lost Pass Book" is at once made upon the child's page in the Ledger. When a child has presented the counterfoil, the Bank will issue a duplicate pass book, charge the child two cents and write the words "Duplicate Pass Book" upon his page in the Ledger.

On receipt of a transfer form, the child's page should be procured from the Ledger of the old school, the pass book number and address changed thereon, a statement of the transfer written on the margin, and the page inserted in its proper place in the Ledger of the new school. If that place is occupied by a blank page bearing the same number, the blank must be destroyed. Also the old index card must be taken out of the cabinet of the old school and the new index card put in the cabinet of the new school. The old Pass Books should be cancelled and sent with the corresponding old index cards to the school that issued them.

At the end of each month the Ledgers should be posted from the Cash Books, posting only the monthly total of deposits for each child as in the Cash Book Column headed "Total for Month." At the same time the ledger balance should be compared with the figures in the Cash Book Column headed "Balance as it appears in Pass Book" and all discrepancies investigated. A return should be made to the Head Office of the Penny Bank, in Toronto, on the printed form supplied for such reports.

During the summer holidays the Ledgers should be sent to Head Office for a period not exceeding a fortnight, previously arranged for, in order that the interest may be computed and added to all accounts that were open on the 30th June last. This interest will be entered in each child's Pass Book the next time he presents it at the Bank.
Miss Mary Meffitt,
No. 1 School,
Cape Croker, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Following up the recent conversation with you in regard to Indian School No. 1 on the Cape Coker Reserve, I wish to lay before you the following facts.

I find that the teacher in charge is an efficient instructor and has her school well in hand, but take exception to the following conditions:

(1) In connection with her residence in a room situate in the building, she has an oratory, wherein an altar is erected, and mass is celebrated. I am creditably informed that in cold days in the winter, the mass is celebrated, outsiders being admitted, and take exception to any public building, much less an undenominational school building conducted under the Department being put to such uses. We freely concede the right of the teacher to use, for her private devotions, any room in her residential portion of the school, but must make strenuous protest against any portion of the school building being used for the public celebration of the mass.

(2) The pupils of the school are about equally divided, but in the Manual Training Department, the material used was put to the use of constructing this altar by the pupils of the school. This much, the teacher
herself, conceded in a conversation with myself.

(3) The teacher has been in the habit of receiving long visits occasionally from her friends, all of which, of course, is quite unobjectionable. But exception must be taken, when such visitors are nuns in the garb. To us, the ostensible object of such visits from these religious ladies, is the familiarizing of the Protestant pupils attending the school with the presence of these religious ladies, and the influence of such visits, upon the Protestant Indian children, with a view of inclining them to the Church of Rome. We consider, that in an undenominational school, this is most objectionable, and has given rise, in this present instance, to no small amount of discontent. Complaints have also been made that the teacher has frequently chided Protestant children attending the school, with the remark "is that all your Protestant training does for you - soulless little things that you are".

We regret that Miss Moffatt's fervor for her church, has betrayed her into showing, on many occasions her excessive zeal, and leading her to forget, that she is a teacher of an undenominational school where religious fervor, along denominational lines cannot be tolerated.

(4) This school also, while it is opened with the Lord's Prayer, yet before repeating it, the Roman Catholic pupils have been instructed to cross themselves. The reading of the Scriptures also, according to the school requirements, have been omitted. Fast days, and feast days, in the Roman Calendar, are also observed in this school, ignoring the fact, that the Protestant children, attending the same, have been deprived of instruction on those days, and the teacher has received her salary for the same, notwithstanding the non-performance of her duties towards her Protestant pupils.

While we wish to make it clear that we are not desirous of disturbing Miss Moffatt, in her position as teacher, and ungrudgingly
admit her high qualifications as an educationalist, still we must emphasize and urge the discontinuance of these conditions that are complained of.

We feel assured that if these matters are called to Miss Moffatt's attention, and the law in the matter clearly explained to her, that our grievances will come to an end.

Awaiting your reply, I am,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

First, it seems you have not yet been notified that Miss Burke, formerly teaching the Indian school at Caughnawaga, had applied some time ago for the position held by Miss Kelly, and her name was to be sent in early in July.

Her acceptance by the Department was looked upon as a certainty since she is reported as having done successful work. So I understand she has been almost sure of the position for which she has especially prepared. You can
readily understand I could not thus disappoint her by taking her place.

Secondly, what really aided me to decide back for a transfer was the hope that Miss Ducharme would succeed me at Cape Croker, for she is a splendid teacher of domestic sciences and has done fine work in Ed. Agriculture—similar to my work at the Cape, so she would be right at home there as I would be in her school and there would be not set back as too often happens when there is a change of teachers.

You know I could not possibly be as selfish as to leave the good people at the Cape in the lurch, even if they are Indians, after their willing correspondence to all my efforts for so many years. Indeed, while I appreciate most fully your very kind consideration which grants my transfer to another school at the same salary, I know receive I would rather continue my work at the Cape until it is well established than run the risk of seeing it neglected and the consequent bad effect on the Indians.

Miss Ducharme and I are spending our vacation together, so we talked the matter over and though we know these communications are generally made through the Agent or respective Missionaries decided in order to avoid delay to address you again. While we do not want to be too persistent we respectfully ask you reconsider the exchange.
in the light of their fair remarks.

Each Indian would give his order, with purchase money or suitable guarantee for payment to the Manager who at an early date would purchase and transport the Reserve all the seed needed. This should be certified seed, free from impurities, from first class dealers. The same could be done for wire fencing or any other commodity needed in quantity.

This would be of advantage to the Indians, especially pure seed. Years ago there were no ox eye daisies or wild mustard. Now the fields are being overrun with these weeds, the seeds of which were bought with seed-pain.

In regard to selling, the Manager, having secured a market for the produce, shall supervise the collection of it, not accepting any below par, provide for transportation, acting or taking place of middleman.

This method of selling will be an encouragement to those who have no land or not much to sell. Hay, grain, potatoes could be sold thus.

Dear Sir,

When you receive this letter from me you may be sure there is something amiss or in need of your assistance. So the object of this letter is to call your attention to the careless manner in which school material is purchased by the Agent.

I do not wish to complain but show no reason why this state of affairs should continue other than...
of the school. This is the usual route by which school supplies purchased by the Agent reaches No. 1.

Send the application. Not hearing anything about the matter for a month or more, I asked the Agent if the Department had authorized him to purchase the articles. Generally, he is not certain, thinks he got a little, but should make out another list as he is going to town and will get the articles. Another month passes and I am fortunate if another list is not required. At last the articles arrive, and frequently are not just what was asked for. But to accept them means not to get them at all or another wait of several months. Two examples will make this clear.

In Sept. 1923, the Department wrote me they had authorized the Agent to purchase supplies for a noon lunch and instructed him to consult me. I waited some weeks and not hearing from him sent him a list, noting especially that eggs and flour ought to be purchased in bulk. After waiting several weeks longer, I heard the articles were in the store and as the Agent did not bring them I got a man to do so. The eggs and flour were in half pound tins, so the Department paid for a lot of empty and useless tins.

In April I asked where the lunch money disappeared. The Agent took it to town. Some time in May I informed...
me it was ready and he would bring it out. June came but no lawn mower. Finally seeing how the porch of his house exposed to wind and weather (I had been as careful not even let it get wet), and wishing to leave the yard in good condition for the holidays, sent a man with a rig to bring it over, but the Agent would not let him have it claiming, as the man states, that he was charged by the Department with these things and would deliver it when he was ready.

A few days later I met the Agent and he informed me he would bring the mower over the next day. When I left it had not been brought to the school.

Now, think this extra work which I have been doing gratuitously for years.
simply for the uplift of the Indians is more than enough without this continual annoyance attending the obtaining of the necessary tools, implements or material.

Any article, after the purchase has been authorized, could be in the school within two weeks. If the merchants in Wainwright are out of the goods, they would send for them if requested to do so.

Received a package of Quarterly School Report Blanks last week. I do not know if that means my report for the June quarter has not yet reached the Department or that the officials are beginning to realize that even such little things as blank forms are not always obtained without delay.
I have not heard the result of the Entrance Examination. I sent two girls, one Indian and the other white. Mrs. Kelchel's daughter. If the Indian girl passes there will be the question of higher education to be decided.

I shall return to the Cape at the end of August—the last heard from since things were as usual.

I trust you will be able to see that there is some improvement in the manner in which school supplies are purchased and delivered. The present method is a losing game.

Thanking you for your interest in my work.

Yours with respect,

OTTAWA, July 28th, 1921.

Sir,

The Department has received several complaints regarding the lack of attention given by you to matters in connection with the Indian schools on the Cape Croker Agency. There has been unnecessary delay on your part in obtaining and delivering supplies which you received authority from the Department to purchase, and also delay in forwarding requests of the teachers for articles required by them.

It is desired that prompt attention on your part be given to requests from the teachers, and that they be forwarded to the Department, and when authority is given you for the purchase of any supplies that you attend to the matter without delay. If these matters are not attended to on your part more promptly in future other arrangements will have to be made in the obtaining of small supplies required by the teachers from time to time.

It is hoped that it will not be necessary to again have to draw your attention to your carelessness in these matters.

OTTAWA, October 19th, 1921.

Dear Miss Moffitt,

I have your letter of the 17th instant, and regret to learn that owing to an outbreak of diphtheria at Cape Croker it was found necessary to close the school. It is hoped that the various cases will soon recover, and that the school will soon reopen, and your work continue to progress favourably.

I am pleased that the Fall Fair was successful, and that there was an improvement in the children's exhibits over that of last year. We will, no doubt, receive Mr. Abraham's report regarding the fair in due course.

It is hoped that the orchestra which you are conducting among the pupils will meet with every success.

THE TWENTY-FIRST ANNUAL REPORT OF THE Penny Bank of Ontario

The Directors have much pleasure in presenting their twenty-first annual report covering the twelve months ended 30th June, 1926.

During the year new branches were opened at Morrisburg, Morpeth and North Mountain, also at the Indian School at Lake Helen in the Nipigon District.

The deposits have increased from $783,087.82 to $820,175.47, an increase of 5% in spite of the unemployment that prevailed during the winter.

The Minister of Education, the Honourable G. Howard Ferguson, has approved of the appointment of Mr. J. K. Littleproud, formerly of London, Ontario, as Penny Bank Inspector for the Province. Mr. Littleproud has already made his influence felt and the Directors look forward with confidence to a great extension of the work of school savings during the coming year.

Sir,

I would beg to advise that owing to the illness of Miss Meffitt, teacher of No 1 Cape Croker School it has not been possible to open this School as yet, after the Xmas holidays. If the teacher illness does not become more severe, she expects to be able to resume her duties on the 7th of January.

I would also wish to report that so far the "flu" is not severe on the Reserve, but there is considerable in the surrounding district and some Schools are closed and I would wish your authority to close Cape Croker Schools if the condition becomes worse in the future. Although the "flu" that is at present prevailing in this neighborhood is of a mild type, it generally takes a week to ten days for it to run its course and if it became severe on the Reserve it may go harder with the Indians than the whites as the Indians have not the proper means of combating it or take the proper means of keeping it from spreading.

I shall advise the Department of any serious conditions that arise from this cause.

Secretary,
Dept of Ind. Affs.,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I would like to report to you on No. 1, Cape Croker Indian Day School.

For the Fall re-opening of School, the Department arranged that Miss Violet Nadjiwen should be engaged as a substitute teacher, in the place of Miss Meffitt who was seriously ill.

I should like to know definitely, if Miss Meffitt, will be able to return to her duties here after the Christmas holidays, as if she is unable to return, it is advisable that a new teacher should be engaged as soon as possible to take charge of this School.

On a recent visit of Inspector McCool to the school, he reported to me that he was very sorry to find Miss Nadjiwen in charge of this school, as he considered her inefficient. On every occasion I visit the school, I find the discipline extremely poor, and altogether the school appears to be going down, the pupils making little progress. To speak personally, I have two children of my own attending, and they are going back in their studies.

If it is impossible for Miss Meffitt to return, I would strongly recommend that a new teacher be engaged for this school.

Secretary,

Madam:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the services of Miss Nadjiwan, who was appointed as substitute teacher at the Cape Croker Indian Day School during your illness.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of Miss Nadjiwan continuing as teacher during your absence, which may be for the balance of the present school year, ending June 30th, next. When she becomes more familiar with the work her services and influence with the Indian pupils will doubtless improve. We are advising Mr. Agent Poste that Miss Nadjiwan is to remain during your absence.

It is noted that you are unable to state when your health will have sufficiently recovered for you to resume duties, but that it will be at least the end of January, next, and probably not before the end of the present school year. Leave of absence will be continued, and, as stated, Miss Nadjiwan can carry on the work until the end of the present school year should you not be able to resume duties before that time. I hope, however, to learn that your health is gradually improving and that you will be able to resume duties earlier than you at present anticipate.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Dr. Scott:

Mrs. Margaret Warder, who has been teaching on the Cape Croker Indian Reserve, has been asked to resign and vacate her residence by the Agent, Mr. Poste. Mrs. Warder has written me regarding what she considers to be very unfair treatment in being turned, with her Mother and her children, out of the house in the dead of winter, and claims that during the year in which she has been teaching at the Sidney Bay School, on the Cape Croker Reserve, that Mr. Moore, the former Inspector, had been well pleased with her work.

At the time of Mr. Moore's transfer to the Muncey Reserve he wrote Mrs. Warder a letter expressing his satisfaction with her teaching, which letter she prizes very highly.

No doubt Mr. Poste will make a report to you giving his reasons for the dismissal of Mrs. Warder, and it probably will be found that he had ample justification for his action. Personally, I have a feeling that she has been very indiscreet in allowing her name to become associated with that of a very clever Indian by the name of Lawrence Keeshig. Keeshig came to see me on her behalf and told me that Mrs. Warder, who was ill, had asked him to take her school for her during her illness, and had suggested that he stay at her house with her.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Cape Croker Agency.

CAPE CROKER INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Miss Violet Nadjiwon, an enfranchised Indian girl holding a second class certificate, is supplying for Miss Moffat at this school. Her services are apparently not very satisfactory. Attendance is poor, the roll has decreased since Miss Nadjiwon assumed duty. Several families complain that their children were not making any progress, rather that they were going back and have taken them from this school and are sending them to the other two schools. Miss Nadjiwon does not appear to be deeply interested in her work; discipline in the class room is poor. Her attitude of indifference and superiority to the pupils' parents has alienated their respect for her. It is stated that she smokes before the pupils in the school grounds and this is not appreciated by the parents. I was unable to see Father Cadot he had gone to Christian Island, but I am informed that he is very much disappointed in Miss Nadjiwon's work as a teacher. From the attitude of the Indians towards her, I believe it would be unwise to retain the services of Miss Nadjiwon after the closing of the school for summer holidays.

Thos, McGookin.

Inspector.

Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Miss Susan Fex, teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School, with reference to the janitor services. It is desired that you inform Mrs. John Taylor that she must perform her duties in accordance with the instructions given to her by Miss Fex. If she does not do so, the Department will be obliged to dispense with her services.

Mrs. Poste has, no doubt, showed you the official letter of the 18th instant with reference to tooth brush drill and it is hoped that the difficulty that occurred regarding this will be overcome.

I may add that Miss Fex has the necessary qualifications and has successfully taught in several other Indian day schools. The Department, therefore, has every confidence in her ability to conduct the Cape Croker School.

As you realize, it is necessary that harmonious relations should exist between all officials on the reserve in order to secure the best results and the Department depends on you to keep matters moving smoothly.

Dear Sir:

I have seen a letter from you to Rev. Father Cadot stating that on my last visit to the Indian School at Cape Croker I told Mr. Thomas Jones that Miss Fex had no qualifications for teaching. On my last visit to Cape Croker School, I drove through the Village both to and from the school without speaking to any person, and I have no recollection whatever of speaking to Mr. Jones about Miss Fex. Chief Charles Jones wrote a letter to me asking for the qualifications of Miss Fex and I replied to him that she had a Lower School certificate from High School, but that would not allow her to teach in a Public School. I did not state that she was not qualified to teach in an Indian School. As a matter of fact, she has better qualifications than two of the Indian teachers on the Saugeen Reserve. I do not mind if my letter to Chief Jones be shown to Miss Fex, as there is nothing in it not in accordance with facts. There is this to be said in favor of Miss Fex, that she takes great interest in the school and the children, much more than many teachers in the public schools.

The situation appears to me that some are not satisfied with Miss Fex and wish to weaken her position and work through the inspector.

Yours sincerely,

At the present time, we have no intimation from any of the teachers of their intention to give up duties during the balance of the present school year. The Public School Inspectors who have inspected these schools report the services of the teachers to be satisfactory. The only school where a change in teacher for the academic year beginning September first, next, might be considered is Scotch Settlement, on the Saugeen reserve. The certificate of the present teacher at this school, Malcolm McIvor, has expired. However, the Inspector states that his services have been satisfactory.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:

I beg to report to you motion No. 2, passed by the Cape Croker council, at their regular meeting held here July 2nd, Chief Johnston and three councillors present.

Moved by S. Elliott and A. Solomon, that we authorize our Indian Agent, to report to the Educational Department with regard to the advisability of having an assistant teacher at the Cape Croker School, to take charge of the kindergarten classes when school re-opens next September. Carried.

Note - I beg to report to the Department, that during the recent visit of Mr. Inspector McGookin to this Reserve, the matter of an assistant teacher for the Cape Croker Day School, was talked over with him, Chief Johnston and myself. The school is a very heavy one, about 45 on the roll, with probably additional pupils after the holidays, and it is felt that the hall known as St. Mary's Hall, near the present school, would accommodate the kindergarten pupils, in the event of the Department granting an assistant teacher. Should this plan be carried out, it would be necessary to supply seats, desks, etc., and other equipment.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Ind. Affs.

Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 9, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, regarding the resolution of the Cape Croker Council of the 2nd instant that an assistant teacher be appointed at the Cape Croker Indian Day School to take charge of the kindergarten classes as from the first of September, next.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds to fit up an extra classroom or to provide the salary of a teacher during the current fiscal year. The teacher of the school will have to carry on under the present arrangements during the next academic year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

June 12, 1936.

Mr. W.R. Tomlinson,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

At our last regular council meeting I was authorized to make enquiries as to the possibility of being allowed an extra (kindergarten) school teacher for one of our day schools on our Reserve, namely: No. 1 School, which is overcrowded, and will be more so after the summer holidays.

It is beyond the power of one teacher to handle the situation. Our council has been promised to use the hall along side of the school to accommodate the extra pupils.

All the parents whose children are attending this school would be most grateful if assistance was given so that their children may have a chance to forge right ahead which is not possible under present conditions.
If you could convince the Educational Authorities the necessity of our request, it would relieve the anxiety, not only the parents, but of the teacher as well.

Since the teacher (Miss Burke) has been pleading for an assistant,

No doubt you will wonder why our Indian Agent does not look after this matter. Well in our experience here they don't seem to pay any attention to him down at Ottawa otherwise I would not be appealing for assistance elsewhere.

Hoping to be enlightened on this matter I am

Yours sincerely,

June 17, 1936.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Doctor McGill,

I enclose you herewith a letter received from the Chief on the Cape Croker Reserve.

There has been an agitation for an additional staff to teach the children there. I know the situation very well and the children have been handicapped, as the school is over-crowded.

I would thank you to take this matter up and I will endeavor to see you personally before leaving Ottawa.

Thanking you for your kind co-

Yours sincerely,

W. R. Tomlinson,
M. P. for Bruce.

Encl.
Ottawa, June 19, 1936.

Dear Mr. Tomlinson,

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with enclosed communication received by you from the Chief of the Cape Croker Band requesting that the services of an extra teacher be engaged for the No. 1 School on that reserve.

In this connection, I have to say that there is no accommodation at this school for an extra classroom and no provision has been made in our Appropriation for the salary of a second teacher or to provide the expense of fitting up a classroom.

I would point out that the highest enrolment at this school during the past fiscal year was forty-nine (49) pupils, with an average attendance of thirty-seven (37). The present teacher is giving good service and is able to satisfactorily handle the number of pupils attending.

It will not be possible to give favourable consideration to the Chief's request during the coming academic year.

Yours truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. R. Tomlinson, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to inform you I have had a request from two of the teachers of this reserve, in regards to their salary checks which they claim they have not received as yet.

Early in July I sent in the form #14 teachers salaries, for the Sydney Bay and Port Elgin schools but omitted to send one for the Cape Croker school because I had no more blank forms.

I received a letter dated July 4th #97-8A from the Dept in which they stated that Teachers Salary Reports were no longer being used, but did not inform me how I was to apply for these salaries.

I would wish to know as soon as possible, if there is any more I can do to procure these salaries for these teachers, and would attend to it at once.

Yours Obediently,

Ottawa, Oct. 30, 1922.

Madam:

I have to inform you that the bonus payable this year to civil servants without dependents has been fixed at $94.50 for those receiving a salary of less than $960 per annum. The Department is endeavouring, however, to secure the permission of His Excellency in Council to pay Indian day school teachers at a flat rate of $15 per month for the 10 teaching months. This proposed arrangement is for the present fiscal year only.

For the last fiscal year, ended March 31st, you were paid a bonus at the rate of $189 per annum, payable in quarterly payments. This year, if authority is received for the proposed arrangement, you will receive a bonus of $15 per teaching month, as follows: June quarter, $45; September quarter, $15; December quarter, $45; and March quarter $45. For the June quarter you were overpaid $2.25, and this amount will be deducted from your salary for the quarter ending 30th September.

I am pleased to inform you that the Deputy Superintendent General has directed that your salary be increased to $800 per annum as from the first of July, 1922. There is, therefore, a balance due on account of salary for the past quarter of $12.50, less the $2.25 mentioned above - or $10.25. This amount will be added to your December quarter cheque, making a total of $210.25.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Miss Mary Moffitt,
Teacher, Indian Day School.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

You may be assured I appreciate this interest very much; it is indeed an incentive to continue doing "my bit" for the improvement of the people among whom I work.

Thanking you for this favour,

Yours with respect,

CANADA
Ottawa, July 17th, 1929.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Miss Mary Moffitt, teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School, in which she advises that, owing to ill health, she will not be able to resume her duties on September 1st but hopes to be able to again take charge of the school about January 1st, next.

It has been decided to appoint Miss Violet Nadjiwan as teacher at this school during Miss Moffitt's absence. Salary will be allowed her at the rate of $80 per teaching month. Please interview her at once and advise the Department if she is willing to accept the school and take up her duties on September 3rd, next.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Arthur C. Poste, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.

Ottawa, July 5, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is approving of the appointment of Miss Frances Morris as teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School for the next school year. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95 per teaching month, and she will begin duties on September 2nd, next. Miss Morris is a fully qualified teacher and has been employed in one of our other Indian schools where she gave excellent service. I have to request that you will give Miss Morris every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school. We have recently been informed by Miss Mary Moffitt, the former teacher, that she will be unable to return and resume duties next school year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, regarding a teacher for the Cape Croker Indian Day School for the coming academic year, to replace Miss Fax, who is giving up duties, I have to say that Miss Sadie J. Burke has been appointed teacher at this school. Miss Burke is a qualified teacher and has had lengthy experience as teacher in Indian schools. She will begin duties on or about September 5th and will be allowed salary at the rate of $95 per teaching month, less 10% during the present fiscal year. I have to request that, when she takes up duties, you will give her every possible help and also continue to assist her in the work during the period she is at this school.

The Department has also received an application from Mr. Jermyn, and he is being informed that we will be unable to utilize his services.

Dear Miss Burke:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the salary rate that can be paid you as teacher of the Cape Croker Indian Day School for the coming academic year.

In reply I beg to say that the salary rating for this school is $95 per teaching month, less 10% during the present fiscal year. Owing to a ruling of the Treasury Board and the Auditor General, this Department has no option in granting an increase over the rate provided. I might point out that this was the salary allowed Miss Fox. I regret not being in a position to increase your salary to the same rate as you received at Lake Helen; but, owing to the regulations mentioned above, it will not be possible to do so.

Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental Circular letter No. 1-1-3, dated April 30th, 1934.

In the third paragraph of this letter, it is stated that:

In the event of any teacher discontinuing duties or being absent from the school for any reason, the Department should be immediately notified, etc.

I have to report that, on November 12th, inst., the day following Remembrance Day, which I understood was not an official holiday, Miss S. Burke, of No. 1, Cape Croker school, decided not to open school, even though all the school pupils appeared at the usual morning hour for lessons. They were returned to their homes by the teacher.

The other two schools on the Reserve remained open as usual all day.

May 25th 1900

Sir,

I enclose herein for Payment as per Resolutions of Council of May 18th accounts for Thomas Solomon as Tenant Officer at Port Elgin a short amount $1.00 also an account for Nancy Richards $1.25 for cleaning the Cape Croker School House. I am your obedient servant,

John McLean
Indian Agent

The Secretary Department
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

3497

Sent May 29th
November 19th, 1900

I have been herein an account for the cleaning of the 3 schools on this Reserve paid to the Parties doing the work by myself these Parties have not been paid to wait for their money until the accounts are paid and to Ottawa and return representing to me that they needed the money badly immediately and the agent has always owed them accounts immediately and if the Department can make the cheque to me as per Resolution of Council it will save me the trouble of having to travel nearly 20 miles to find these Parties and obtain their signatures to the separate cheques all of which is respectfully submitted.

I have the honor to be your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence and my letter of July 4th, 1905 in the matter of an account and cash paid by me for books and other money given to the pupils of the Cape Breton, Sydney Bay and Port Elgin School as prizes amounting to nearly $15.00

I beg to say that I have been unable to get an account in detail from the S. Easton Committee, other than the one I have already sent the Dept.

I enclose the Resolution of the Indian Council, voting the money on June 16th, and I do not remember ever having received a cheque to record me for the payments I then made, there being no time to get a cheque from the Dept., and I let go the money in advance. The only thing I can do is to get the Teachers to sign a list of the Books that were distributed to each school, they were good value and why he could not give a detailed statement I do not know. Will the Department kindly look into this matter.

I think a voucher was made for this before your obedient servant,

John M. Irwin
